results.body:
Samir Nasri of Manchester City celebrates scoring the first goal during the Barclays Premier League match between Manchester City and West Ham United at the Etihad Stadium on May 11, 2014 in Manchester, England.  (GETTY)
Manchester City calmly overpowered West Ham United 2-0 to secure their second Premier League title in three seasons in a party atmosphere at the Etihad Stadium on Sunday.
 Liverpool beat Newcastle United 2-1 at Anfield to finish two points behind the champions but goals by Samir Nasri and Vincent Kompany sparked wild celebrations at City whose heavyweight squad came out on top at the end of a thrilling and fluctuating title race.
 Nasri calmed City nerves with a fierce strike in the 39th minute and captain Kompany's neat finish four minutes after halftime put the hosts in cruise control, rounding off a superb debut season for manager Manuel Pellegrini.
 "It's a very special time.  My first year is not easy to get used to English football but I think I managed a great group of players," Pellegrini said after the trophy was presented on the pitch.
 "It was a very special because we've never been at the top of the table but six games away I told my players we needed to change and they believed in me.  They are a special group." "
For Chilean Pellegrini, the first non-European manager to win the Premier League, it was a first league title since he won the Clausura with River Plate in Argentina in 2003 and a maiden success on this continent.
 "I'm just so happy for the manager as well because it's his first title in Europe, it's amazing," Nasri added.
 The atmosphere at Anfield was muted as an own goal from Martin Skrtel put Newcastle ahead in the first half, but goals from Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge ensured they ended with victory against opponents who had Shola Ameobi and Paul Dummett sent off.
 Chelsea had to settle for third spot after coming from a goal down to win 2-1 at Cardiff City, ending a trophyless first season back in England for manager Jose Mourinho.
 Tottenham Hotspur comfortably beat Aston Villa 3-0 to finish sixth and clinch a place in next season's Europa League, meaning deposed champions Manchester United, who drew their final match of a terrible season 1-1 against Southampton, will not play in Europe next season for the first time in 24 years.
 Norwich City's relegation was confirmed with a 2-0 home defeat by Arsenal and they will join Cardiff and Fulham in the Championship next season.
 PATIENT PROBING
City began by patiently probing, just as they did against Aston Villa in midweek, with their first chance falling to David Silva who blasted over after 10 minutes.
 Minutes later and with the teams still deadlocked, a roar echoed around the Etihad stadium as news filtered through that Liverpool had fallen a goal behind, easing the tension before City opened the scoring.
 Yaya Toure laid the ball inside to Nasri 30 metres from goal.  He dropped his shoulder, strode forward and unleashed a vicious drive low into the bottom corner.
 If that goal was enough to put the champagne on ice, the corks started popping four minutes after the restart when a corner struck the back of Edin Dzeko, falling for Kompany who swivelled and lashed home from close range.
 There was a sense of deflation at Anfield from the moment Skrtel fly-kicked a harmless Yoan Gouffran cross past Simon Mignolet into the back of the net.
 Radios pressed against the ears of fans in the stands told the home crowd that City were cruising to victory and Liverpool's wait for a top-flight title was likely to go on beyond 24 years.
 The second half brought some cheer as Daniel Agger scored Liverpool's 100th goal of the season to level by hooking in at the far post while Daniel Sturridge netted a second in as many minutes, tapping home in similar fashion.
 Ameobi was sent off for dissent and Dummett for a clumsy challenge as the dejected Liverpool players were left to ponder what might have been.
 "I'm absolutely devastated," Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard told Sky Sports.
 "Personally gutted and gutted for the fans.  We can't be too down because it's been a great season and we have to bounce back for next season.  Hopefully, we can keep improving but we have to congratulate Man City because they've been the best for 38 games." "
results.title: Clinical Manchester City wrap up title in style

results.body:
Vincent Kompany lifts the Premier League trophy following Manchester City's 2-0 win over West Ham at Etihad Stadium on Sunday.  Photo: Alex Livesey
London: Manchester City secured a second Premier League title in three seasons by comfortably defeating West Ham United 2-0 at home on Sunday.
 City needed only a point to claim the championship ahead of Liverpool, but goals in each half from Samir Nasri and Vincent Kompany meant they completed their mission with room to spare.
 Victory took City's goals tally to 102 - one short of Chelsea's Premier League record from 2009/10 - and made Chilean Manuel Pellegrini the first non-European manager to win an English top-flight title.
 Liverpool, having led the table with three games to play, finished two points behind City after coming from behind to win 2-1 at home to Newcastle United, who had Shola Ameobi and Paul Dummett sent off.
 Advertisement
David Silva, Sergio Aguero and Aleksandar Kolarov all threatened for City before Nasri put them ahead in the 39th minute, gathering a pass from Yaya Toure and arrowing a 22-yard drive into the bottom-left corner.
 West Ham striker Andy Carroll deflected a shot from Silva onto the post in first-half stoppage time, before Kompany doubled City's lead early in the second half by stabbing home from a corner.
 The home fans celebrated with their customary 'Poznan' dance - bouncing up and down with their backs to the game - and then flooded onto the pitch at the final whistle.
 Liverpool went into their last game of the campaign with a slim hope of winning a first league title since 1990, but they fell behind in the 20th minute when Martin Skrtel sliced Yoan Gouffran's cross into his own net.
 However, carbon-copy goals by Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge, both of whom volleyed in Steven Gerrard free-kicks, turned the game around in the space of two minutes in the second half.
 Agger's goal was Liverpool's 100th in the league and made this the first English top-flight season in which two teams have reached that milestone since 1960-61.
 Tottenham Hotspur secured the last available Europa League berth by crushing Aston Villa 3-0 through a Paulinho strike, a Nathan Baker own goal and an Emmanuel Adebayor penalty, all of which arrived before half-time.
 Spurs' victory means that Manchester United will not play in Europe next season for the first time since the 1989/90 season.
 United drew 1-1 at Southampton in Ryan Giggs's final game as interim manager, last season's champions finishing 22 points below cross-town rivals City in seventh place after a miserable campaign.
 United captain Nemanja Vidic, playing his last game for the club, was left with a bloodied nose by Ricky Lambert as the Southampton striker put the hosts in front in the 28th minute.
 Juan Mata equalised for United with a sumptuous free-kick early in the second half.
 Norwich City's relegation was confirmed after they lost 2-0 at home to Arsenal, although they were already assured of joining Fulham and Cardiff City in the Championship.
 Aaron Ramsey's sublime 53rd-minute volley put Arsenal ahead, with Carl Jenkinson adding a second goal shortly after.
 Arsenal's FA Cup final opponents Hull City finished the campaign by losing 2-0 at home to fifth-place Everton, who prevailed through goals from James McCarthy and Romelu Lukaku.
 Third-placed Chelsea, meanwhile, came from behind to win 2-1 at relegated Cardiff, with Andre Schurrle and Fernando Torres securing victory after Craig Bellamy had put the Welsh club ahead.
 Ashley Cole, whose contract is due to expire, captained Chelsea on what may have been his last appearance.
 Elsewhere, Swansea City spoilt Sunderland's survival party with a 3-1 win at the Stadium of Light, while Stoke City won 2-1 at West Bromwich Albion and Fulham drew 2-2 at home to Crystal Palace.
results.title: Manchester City clinch Premier League title

results.body:
LONDON: Manchester City secured a second Premier League title in three seasons by comfortably defeating West Ham United 2-0 at a jubilant Etihad Stadium on Sunday.
 City effectively needed only a point to claim the championship ahead of Liverpool, but goals in each half from Samir Nasri and captain Vincent Kompany meant that they completed their mission with room to spare.
 The result took City's goals tally to 102 -- one short of Chelsea's Premier League record from 2009-10 -- and made Chilean Manuel Pellegrini the first non-European manager to win an English top-flight title.
 "I think that I manage a great group of players, a great institution and great fans," said Pellegrini.
 "I must be calm during the game to take decisions but when you achieve the title, I think the whole year shows a lot of work we did at difficult moments in the year and I think this is the best team in the league." "
Liverpool, who led the table with three games to play, finished two points below City in second place after coming from behind to win 2-1 at home to Newcastle United, who had Shola Ameobi and Paul Dummett sent off.
 David Silva, Sergio Aguero and Aleksandar Kolarov all threatened for City before Nasri put them ahead in the 39th minute, gathering a pass from Yaya Toure and arrowing a 22-yard drive into the bottom-left corner.
 West Ham striker Andy Carroll deflected a shot from Silva onto the post in first-half stoppage time, before Kompany doubled City's lead early in the second half by stabbing in from a corner.
 The home fans celebrated with their customary 'Poznan' dance -- bouncing up and down with their backs to the game -- and then flooded onto the pitch in delight at the final whistle.
 "Forget about the money and everything," Kompany told Sky Sports after hoisting the trophy aloft beneath a flurry of blue and white tickertape.
 "As a kid, you grow up and dream of lifting trophies.  I feel like I am living that dream when I do this." "
Liverpool went into their game against Newcastle with a slim hope of winning a first league title since 1990, but they fell behind in the 20th minute when Martin Skrtel sliced Yoan Gouffran's cross into his own net.
 However, carbon-copy goals by Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge, both of whom volleyed in Steven Gerrard free-kicks, turned the game around in the space of two minutes in the second half.
 Agger's goal was Liverpool's 100th in the league and made this the first English top-flight season in which two teams have reached that milestone since 1960-61.
 "It's been an incredible journey this year, so to finish with 12 wins out of 14 is an incredible achievement by the players," said Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers.
 "We've made the supporters dream and that is our job to do that." "
Tottenham Hotspur secured the last available Europa League berth by crushing Aston Villa 3-0 through a Paulinho strike, a Nathan Baker own goal and an Emmanuel Adebayor penalty, all of which arrived before half-time.
 Spurs' victory means that Manchester United will not play in Europe next season for the first time since 1989-90.
 United drew 1-1 at Southampton in Ryan Giggs's final game as interim manager, which saw last season's champions finish 22 points below cross-town rivals City in seventh place after a miserable campaign.
 United captain Nemanja Vidic, playing his last game for the club, was left with a bloodied nose by Ricky Lambert as the Southampton striker put the hosts in front in the 28th minute.
 Juan Mata equalised for United with a sumptuous free-kick early in the second half.
 "It's been an experience with ups and downs," said Giggs.  "I've enjoyed it and I didn't want the second half to end.  The fans were great and the players were great and I loved it." "
Norwich City's relegation was confirmed after they lost 2-0 at home to Arsenal, although they were already practically assured of joining Fulham and Cardiff City in the Championship.
 Aaron Ramsey's sublime 53rd-minute volley put Arsenal ahead, with Carl Jenkinson adding a second goal shortly after.
 Arsenal's FA Cup final opponents Hull City finished the campaign by losing 2-0 at home to fifth-place Everton, who prevailed through goals from James McCarthy and Romelu Lukaku.
 Third-place Chelsea, meanwhile, came from behind to win 2-1 at relegated Cardiff, with Andre Schurrle and Fernando Torres securing victory after Craig Bellamy had put the Welsh club ahead.
 Ashley Cole, whose contract is due to expire, captained Chelsea on what may have been his last appearance.
 Elsewhere, Swansea City spoilt Sunderland's survival party with a 3-1 win at the Stadium of Light, while Stoke City won 2-1 at West Bromwich Albion and Fulham drew 2-2 at home to Crystal Palace.

results.title: City beats West Ham to clinch EPL title

results.body:

results.title: Clinical Man City wrap up title in style

results.body:
Manchester City's captain, Vincent Kompany (centre), holds the Cup and celebrates with teammates after being crowned Premier League champions in England yesterday.  Manchester City blanked West Ham United 2-0 to clinch the title at the Etihad Stadium in Manchester, England.  - AP
The songs and the chanting started well before the final whistle this time, and as it blew, Manchester City fans, setting off blue flares, streamed on to the pitch in their thousands.
 For the second time in three seasons, a team so long the underdogs are the Premier League champion - and it didn't need any last-minute miracles this time.  Without any of the drama of its injury-time comeback on the last day in 2012, City secured just the fourth title in its history with a comfortable 2-0 victory over West Ham yesterday.
 "It was my first season in the Premier League and I had to change a lot of things," said City manager Manuel Pellegrini, who also won the League Cup in March.  "It's amazing we are here after just one year." "
After an edgy start at the Etihad Stadium, Samir Nasri scored with a shot from outside the area in the 39th minute and Vincent Kompany added the second from close range shortly after the break to let fans celebrate for much of the second half.  The win meant Liverpool had no chance of catching up, and finished two points behind in second despite a 2-1 win over Newcastle.
 "We are building a club, not just a team," captain Vincent Kompany said.  "The past is the past, but surely we have our place in the future.  Next year, we have to be even better.  If we want to be a big club, this has to be one of many." "
City spent most of their 134-year history in the shadow of neighbours Manchester United, but have seen their fortunes transformed after being taken over by Abu Dhabi owners, who have poured money into the club to turn it into a new power in English football.
 This year it wasn't United but another traditional power - Liverpool - that provided the toughest challenge to the upstarts.
 A month ago, it seemed as if Liverpool would end its 24-year title drought after starting as 33-1 outsiders, but the 18-time champions faltered in the final weeks.  Although Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge took Liverpool to 101 league goals in Sunday's win over Newcastle, the campaign ended with players embarking on a downbeat lap of appreciation at Anfield.
 "People have looked at us and asked, have they coped with the pressure?  I think 12 wins out of 14 shows we clearly have," Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers said.  "For us, it's been a wonderful campaign of growth and development ... and we will improve.  We'll be ready to fight again, but now we've got the belief." "
On a final day lacking drama, sixth place was settled with Tottenham denying Manchester United the final Europa League spot by beating Aston Villa 3-0 as the deposed champions were held to a 1-1 draw at Southampton.
 There could be a series of managerial changes now, with Tim Sherwood set to leave Tottenham after missing out on Champions League qualification, despite signing an 18-month deal in December to replace Andre Villas-Boas.
 Results: Cardiff 1-2 Chelsea; Fulham 2-2 Crystal Palace; Hull 0-2 Everton; Liverpool 2-1 Newcastle; Man City 2-0 West Ham; Norwich 0-2 Arsenal; Southampton 1-1 Man Utd; Sunderland 1-3 Swansea; Tottenham 3-0 Aston Villa; West Brom 1-2 Stoke.
 Second-half goals by Andre Shurrle and Fernando Torres saw Chelsea complete a comeback win over relegated Cardiff.  The Bluebirds took the lead when Craig Bellamy's left-foot shot was deflected off Cezar Azpilicueta past a wrong-footed Mark Schwarzer.  Below-par Chelsea finally struck back in the 72nd minute when Schurrle fired a rebound high into the net after David Marshall's save from Azpilicueta.  Torres' 11th goal of the season from six yards completed the comeback.
 Chris David scored a fine goal in added time to earn Fulham a draw against Crystal Palace in the Barclays Premier League.  Dwight Gayle turned Joel Ward's drive past David Stockdale from close range to put Tony Pulis' visitors ahead just before the half-hour.  Cauley Woodrow curled in from Hugo Rodallega's pass to pull the Cottagers level before Gayle scored a free kick.  But David collected the ball near halfway and hit a looping shot in off the bar from 25 yards to secure a draw.
 Romelu Lukaku scored in his final loan appearance for Everton as the Toffees beat Hull to finish the season with their best points tally for 27 years.  Lukaku slotted home just after half-time, with James McCarthy having earlier fired the visitors ahead with his first goal for the club.  The Tigers, evidently with one eye on next weekend's FA Cup final, rarely tested away goalkeeper Tim Howard.  But in finishing 16th, Steve Bruce's side have had a successful season.
 GOALS:-LIVERPOOL: AGGER 63; STURRIDGE 65.  NEWCASTLE: SKRTEL 20 OG.
 Liverpool came from behind to defeat nine-man Newcastle but were denied the Barclays Premier League title by Manchester City's victory over West Ham.  Needing a win and a City defeat to capture the league, Liverpool fell behind to a Martin Skrtel own goal.  But the match turned around when Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge converted Steven Gerrard free kicks.  Newcastle striker Shola Ameobi saw red for dissent and teammate Paul Dummett was sent off for fouling Luis Suarez.
 Manchester City won a second Barclays Premier League title in three years as goals from Samir Nasri and captain Vincent Kompany secured victory over West Ham.  The Sky Blues, needing a draw to guarantee being English champions for the fourth time, dominated before Nasri fired in off the post from 20 yards.  David Silva hit the bar before half-time, but Kompany prodded in from six yards to seal a fifth win in a row.  City finished two points ahead of Liverpool, who beat Newcastle 2-1.
 Norwich City's relegation from the Barclays Premier League was confirmed as they lost to Arsenal.  The Canaries, who were realistically down already barring a set of highly unlikely results, started brightly and Nathan Redmond forced a good save.  But the Gunners dominated most of the game and Aaron Ramsey showed fantastic technique to volley Olivier Giroud's lofted cross into the top corner.  Carl Jenkinson sealed it with the first goal of his career, a deflected effort.
 Manchester United drew at Southampton in what is expected to be Ryan Giggs's last match as United's interim manager.  The Saints took a controversial lead when Rickie Lambert shot past David De Gea, despite appearing to foul Nemanja Vidic in the build-up to the goal.  Juan Mata equalised with a curling 25-yard free kick in the second half.
 GOALS:-SUNDERLAND: BORINI 50.  SWANSEA: DYER 7; EMNES 14; BONY 54.
 Sunderland's superb end-of-season surge to safety ended in slightly disappointing fashion against Swansea.  Nathan Dyer and Marvin Emnes struck inside the first 15 minutes.  Fabio Borini pulled one back straight after the restart, but Wilfried Bony soon restored the visitors' two-goal lead with his 25th goal of the season.
 Tottenham beat Manchester United to a place in next season's Europa League after an easy win over Aston Villa.  Paulinho cut through the heart of the Villa defence to shoot past Brad Guzan to put Spurs in early control.  Nathan Baker headed in an own goal from Danny Rose's cross before Emmanuel Adebayor scored from the spot.  Spurs finished the season sixth, three points shy of their total last term, in what could be boss Tim Sherwood's last game in charge.
 Charlie Adam's late goal gave Stoke victory at West Brom as they completed their best league season since 1975.  City had the best of the first half and deservedly led when Gareth McAuley turned in Marko Arnautovic's cross.  The Baggies equalised through Stephane Sessegnon's low finish, but Adam's strike from distance settled it.  Stoke finish ninth on 50 points - their highest in six seasons back in the top flight - while West Brom are 17th, three points above the relegation zone.
results.title: Manchester City clinch title

results.body:
Manchester City clinched a second Premier League title in three seasons with a 2-0 win over West Ham United on Sunday that sent their Etihad Stadium into raptures and condemned Liverpool to second place.
 Blue and white ticker tape rained down and fans poured on to the pitch at the final whistle as City, who only needed a draw to win the trophy, finished two points clear of Liverpool whose campaign ended with a 2-1 win over Newcastle United.
 Samir Nasri calmed City nerves by drilling them ahead in 39th minute and captain Vincent Kompany's neat finish four minutes after halftime put the hosts in cruise control, rounding off a superb debut season for manager Manuel Pellegrini.
 "It's an amazing feeling.  My second title in three years.  It was an amazing league the whole year," Frenchman Nasri told Sky Sports.
 "There are no words to explain my feelings now." "
For Chilean Pellegrini it was a first league title since he won the Clausura with River Plate in Argentina in 2003 and a maiden success in Europe.
 "I'm just so happy for the manager as well because it's his first title in Europe, it's amazing," Nasri added.
 The atmosphere at Anfield was muted as an own goal from Martin Skrtel put Newcastle ahead in the first half, but goals from Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge ensured they ended with victory against opponents who had Shola Ameobi and Paul Dummett sent off.
 Chelsea had to settle for third spot after coming from a goal down to win 2-1 at Cardiff City, ending a trophyless first season back in England for manager Jose Mourinho.
 Tottenham Hotspur comfortably beat Aston Villa 3-0 to finish sixth and clinch a place in next season's Europa League, meaning deposed champions Manchester United, who drew their final match of a terrible season 1-1 against Southampton, will not play in Europe next season for the first time in 24 years.
 Norwich City's relegation was confirmed with a 2-0 home defeat by Arsenal and they will join Cardiff and Fulham in the Championship next season.
results.title: Manchester City win Premier League title

results.body:
London (AFP) - Manchester City secured a second Premier League title in three seasons by comfortably defeating West Ham United 2-0 at a jubilant Etihad Stadium on Sunday.
 City effectively needed only a point to claim the championship ahead of Liverpool, but goals in each half from Samir Nasri and Vincent Kompany meant that they completed their mission with room to spare.
 Victory took City's goals tally to 102 -- one short of Chelsea's Premier League record from 2009-10 -- and made Chilean Manuel Pellegrini the first non-European manager to win an English top-flight title.
 Liverpool, who led the table with three games to play, finished two points below City in second place after coming from behind to win 2-1 at home to Newcastle United, who had Shola Ameobi and Paul Dummett sent off.
 David Silva, Sergio Aguero and Aleksandar Kolarov all threatened for City before Nasri put them ahead in the 39th minute, gathering a pass from Yaya Toure and arrowing a 22-yard drive into the bottom-left corner.
 West Ham striker Andy Carroll deflected a shot from Silva onto the post in first-half stoppage time, before Kompany doubled City's lead early in the second half by stabbing home from a corner.
 The home fans celebrated with their customary 'Poznan' dance -- bouncing up and down with their backs to the game -- and then flooded onto the pitch in delight at the final whistle.
 Liverpool went into their last game of the campaign with a slim hope of winning a first league title since 1990, but they fell behind in the 20th minute when Martin Skrtel sliced Yoan Gouffran's cross into his own net.
 However, carbon-copy goals by Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge, both of whom volleyed in Steven Gerrard free-kicks, turned the game around in the space of two minutes in the second half.
 Agger's goal was Liverpool's 100th in the league and made this the first English top-flight season in which two teams have reached that milestone since 1960-61.
 - United miss out on Europe -
Tottenham Hotspur secured the last available Europa League berth by crushing Aston Villa 3-0 through a Paulinho strike, a Nathan Baker own goal and an Emmanuel Adebayor penalty, all of which arrived before half-time.

results.title: Man City stroll to Premier League title

results.body:
LONDON - The curtain fell on one of the most dramatic Premier League title races for years on Sunday with Manchester City acclaimed as champions while Liverpool looked on from the wings dreaming of what might have been.
 City avoided any last-minute twists in a season when the lead at the top changed hands 24 times to beat visitors West Ham United 2-0 ensuring the league trophy returned to the Etihad Stadium for the second time in three seasons.
 Liverpool came from behind to win 2-1 against a Newcastle United side that finished with nine men at Anfield but it proved an empty victory for manager Brendan Rodgers, captain Steven Gerrard and the rest of the deflated team in red.
 Liverpool's only hope of ending a 24-year wait to be crowned champions was if City lost and they won but that outcome never looked remotely likely as Manuel Pellegrini's side dominated West Ham from the first minute to the last.
 There was a massive roar at the Etihad when the final table was flashed on to the giant screens showing City with 86 points, Liverpool on 84, Chelsea 82, Arsenal 79, Everton 72, Tottenham Hotspur 69 and deposed champions Manchester United on 64.
 Goals from Samir Nasri after 39 minutes and captain Vincent Kompany 10 minutes later ensured City's triumphant march to the title was completed with a comfortable victory.
 City's Chilean coach Pellegrini, in his first season in England, became the first non-European to guide a team to the English title and told Sky Sports: "It's a very special time.
 "My first year is not easy to get used to English football but I think I managed a great group of players.
 "But big teams cannot be satisfied with one title.  It's very important.  Celebrate, today, tomorrow and Monday and on Tuesday start working for next season because this club and players deserve more titles." "
Chelsea finished third after a 2-1 win at bottom side Cardiff City while fourth-placed Arsenal rubber-stamped Norwich City's drop into the second tier with a 2-0 win at Carrow Road.
 Aaron Ramsey scored a stunning goal from an acute angle while defender Carl Jenkinson got his first for the Gunners.
 Norwich and Cardiff will play in the Championship next term along with Fulham, who had already been relegated and ended 13 years as a Premier League club with a 2-2 home draw in a London derby with Crystal Palace.
 The only other issue to be decided on the final day of the season was which club would finish sixth and take the final Europa League spot along with fifth-placed Everton and FA Cup finalists Hull City who meet Arsenal at Wembley next week.
 Tottenham Hotspur duly clinched it with a 3-0 home win over Aston Villa thanks to first-half goals from Brazil midfielder Paulinho, a Nathan Baker own goal and an Emmanuel Adebayor penalty in what could be Tim Sherwood's last match in charge.
 Manchester United would have finished sixth if they had won at Southampton and Spurs had lost but United's miserable season petered out with a 1-1 draw at St Mary's in Ryan Giggs' last match as interim manager.
 A Juan Mata freekick in the second half cancelled out Rickie Lambert's opener for the Saints as United finished seventh a year after being crowned champions.
 It was their lowest finish since they came sixth in 1991 and there will be no European football at Old Trafford next season for the first time since 1990.
 BLUE HALF
There will still be European football in Manchester though, albeit in the blue half of the city as City challenge for the Champions League.
 While there were scenes of unbridled joy at The Etihad, 30 miles away at Anfield the atmosphere was subdued as an own goal from Martin Skrtel saw Newcastle ahead at the break.
 However, second-half strikes by Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge ensured Liverpool ended the season with a win against opponents who had Shola Ameobi and Paul Dummett sent off.
 Liverpool have now finished runners-up four times since winning their last title in 1990 but, despite the disappointing end to the season, coach Brendan Rodgers was upbeat.
 "It's been brilliant," he told Sky Sports.
 "We've been on an incredible journey this year.  To finish with 12 wins and a draw is an incredible achievement.
 "It was a tough game for us today so it was a great way to finish.  It was unfortunate not to win the title but we've shown great hope for the future going forward.
 "It's a huge privilege to be manager.  We've helped the supporters dream here and we're a team on the up and we have momentum.
 "I don't think we failed to cope with the pressure.  We won 12 and drew one and we just had an unfortunate result against Chelsea.  We were just unable to get the result.
 "This has been an incredible run for us.  This is group that could cope with the pressure but we'll learn from this." "
Skipper Steven Gerrard, who has never won the title during his 16 years with Liverpool, had a different view.
 "I'm absolutely devastated.  Personally gutted and gutted for the fans," he told the BBC.
 But he added: "We can't be too down because it's been a great season and we have to bounce back for next season.  Hopefully we can keep improving but we have to congratulate Man City because they've been the best for 38 games." "

results.title: City stay calm to clinch second Premier League title in three years

results.body:
* In pictures: the Premier League final day
* All today's final scores
* The final Premier League table
* Like Telegraph Sport on Facebook
PREMIER LEAGUE MATCH REPORTS
Cardiff City 1-2 Chelsea
Fulham 2-2 Crystal Palace
Hull City 0-2 Everton
Norwich City 0-2 Arsenal
Southampton 1-1 Manchester United
Sunderland 1-3 Swansea City
Tottenham 3-0 Aston Villa
West Brom 1-2 Stoke City
Liverpool 2-1 Newcastle United
Manchester City 2-0 West Ham
17.34 This is the moment Vincent Kompany got his hands on the Premier League trophy again.  Which seems a decent note on which to end this liveblog.  Congratulations to Manchester City, commiserations to Liverpool.  Thanks for your company.  Bye!
17.31 The magnificent and endearingly bonkers Pablo Zabaleta is bouncing up and down, singing Rocking All Over The World in front of the camera.  "Maybe I'll be a singer in another life ...  All our work throughout the year and it finishes like this, it's amazing.  We need to be proud.  We know the owners have been spending big to make this happen, so it's time to enjoy it.  And we'll work even more to bring more success to this club." "
17.27 The manager Manuel Pellegrini is talking on Sky: "It feels very special because it's my first year in England.  I think that I manage a great group of players.  I have to be calm during a game because I have to take decisions.  We were the best team in the Premier League.  It was a very special season for us because we were never really top of the table, we didn't start well, but the most important thing we did this year was that we did not change our way of playing even when we lost games away from home early in the season.  Big teams cannot be satisfied with just one title.  It's very important we start working for next season straight away.  These players deserve more titles." "
Now Pellegrini is getting the bumps from his players, who clearly adore him.  That moment is an insight into the unity of City's dressing-room, especially in view of the problems some of them had with Roberto Mancini.
 17.18 Now the players are receiving their medals, with particular roars for, Silva, Zabaleta, Nasri, Aguero and, most of all, the magnificent Yaya Toure.  Finally, Vincent Kompany steps forward to lift the Premier League for the second time!
17.14 The players emerge again, led by Manuel Pellegrini.  Nice guys, it seems, can finish first.  This is his first league title since (I think) winning the Primera Division with River Plate in 2002-03.  He has made the dressing-room an extremely happy place, and developed a team who play brilliant attacking football.
 17.12 Somewhere in Turkey, Roberto Mancini is congratulating himself on winning a second Premier League title.
 17.10 Here's Henry Winter's report from the Etihad on City's title-clinching victory.  Mark Ogden has picked five key games that won City the title.  And here's Jonathan Liew's report from Anfield, where Liverpool ended a season that was both heartbreaking and magnificent with a 2-1 victory over Newcastle.
 17.07 The DJ at City is going through the usual collection of songs: We Are The Champions, Wonderwall and, er, One Step Beyond.  The atmosphere is wonderful - without the delirious disbelief of 2012 but, as Niall Quinn, with the joy and sheer contentment that comes with doing it for a second time.
 17.04 Sky have set theit title-winning montage to this particular song.  The presentation is being prepared, with the last eejits having finally done one from the field.  "It's better to win the league second time round," says Graeme Souness on Sky.  "The first time round, it goes in a flash." "
17.02 The latest celebrations from the Etihad on Sky Sports 1: an advert for the BLT Quad Wrap at KFC.
 16.59 This is the final Premier League table.  Two teams with over 100 goals in the English top flight for the first time since 1960-61.
 16.56 Joe Hart: "That was a scrum out there at the final whistle.  That's the kind of rumble you want to be in.  You can't repeat what happened last time, against QPR.  This year we've come strong at the end when we needed to.  We're all winners, we've got strong personalities, we've got great backroom staff.  I've been here for a while; the boys that come in, they but into it.  It's been a great year for me, a really exciting year." "
Twitter: Henry Winter - #mcfc fans in stands at Etihad calling for others to get off the pitch so trophy presentation can take place.  Fans on pitch now being booed
16.55 Sergio Aguero: "This is better than the QPR game.  The QPR game?  Never again, please!"
16.52 Some of the players are struggling to get off the field.  Others don't want to: Matija Nastasic is cavorting joyfully with the fans.  Here's Samir Nasri: "It's an amazing feeling.  It's my second in three years.  It was an amazing title race.  There are no words to explain our feeling right now.  I'm so happy for the manager as it's his first title in Europe.  He has done an amazing job.  He remained calm the whole season, and he wanted us to play attractive football.  It is a pleasure to work with him.  The atmosphere in the dressing-room ... we've been friends this year, and everyone put their ego on the side.  The Liverpool game against Chelsea, that's the twist of the season." "
MANCHESTER CITY ARE CHAMPIONS FOR THE FOURTH TIME: 1937, 1968, 2012 and now 2014.  Congratulations to Manuel Pellegrini and his team, who have scored 102 goals and won the league in enormous style.  There's a full pitch invasion, with Vincent Kompany and all the other players being mobbed.  Even poor old Martin Demichelis is feeling the love.  It was a comfortable day in the end, with none of the trauma of QPR two years ago.
 16.47 Sergio Aguero has an unfathomable off-the-ball kick at Mark Noble, prompting a lively, shove-based exchange between both sets of players.  Aguero is a bit lucky to only receive a yellow card; Noble is also booked, goodness knows what for.  A slightly odd note on which to end a memorable season for City.
 16.44 Newcastle are down to nine men at Anfield, with the substitute Paul Dummett given a straight red for a clash of legs with Luis Suarez.  It's a ridiculous decision.
 GOAL!  West Brom 1-2 Stoke (Adam) Stoke's wonderful season ends with a late winner from Charlie Adam.
 16.42 Raheem Stirling has a goal disallowed at Anfield; he was seven or eight yards offside.  Yaya Toure has limped off with what looks like a hamstring injury.  Alvaro Negredo comes on, the beast at the feast, or something.  It looks precautionary with Toure but will be a concern ahead of the World Cup.
 GOAL!  Fulham 1-2 Crystal Palace (Gayle) Dwight Gayle slams in a free-kick, his fourth goal in seven days, and Crystal Palace look set for a fourth consecutive away win.
 16.40 A summary of the excitement in the last few minutes:
16.36 Another wicked free-kick from Gerrard on the right is headed wide by Agger, stretching six yards from goal.  He should have scored.
 GOAL!  Cardiff 1-2 Chelsea (Torres) Chelsea lead through Fernando Torres, while Samri Nasri almost embroiders City's title with a beautiful goal.  Toure played a gorgeous scooped pass over the top that Nasri swished firmly towards goal, only for Adrian to save with his right foot.
 Twitter: Paul Hayward - Andy Carroll replaced shortly after a first touch so bad that it went out for a Man City goal kick.  Hasn't developed as a player.
 16.31 The little genius, David Silva, gets a lovely ovation from the Manchester City fans as he is replaced by James Milner.  City are enjoying that wonderful window you sometimes get in sport when you know you have won something but you haven't been confirmed as winners, so you get maybe 20 minutes or half an hour to breathe it all in while the action is still going on.
 GOAL!  Cardiff 1-1 Chelsea (Schurrle) Ameobi is sent off, and now Schurrle scores for Chelsea.
 16.28 Liverpool look in the mood to win by a few now; there is an urgency about their attacking, with Sturridge's shot inadvertently blocked by one of his own team.  The pace is a little more relaxed at the Etihad, where the clock is ticking down - or rather tiki-takaing down, as City pass the ball at their leisure.
 16.26 It seems Ameobi was sent off for dissent before the kick-off.  In fact he was booked first, and then shown a red card a couple of seconds later.
 16.23 When Newcastle crumble, they do so in style: Shola Ameobi has received a straight red card before the kick off!  Nobody seems to know why he was sent off.
 GOAL!  Liverpool 2-1 Newcastle (Sturridge) Liverpool have scored a carbon copy of Agger's goal, this time fro Daniel Sturridge.  Those were eerily similar, both from brilliant free-kicks taken by Gerrard.
 GOAL!  Liverpool 1-1 Newcastle (Agger) Daniel Agger scores Liverpool's 100th goal of the season, acrobatically beating Krul at the near post from Gerrard's superb deep free-kick.
 GOAL!  Norwich 0-2 Arsenal (Jenkinson); Fulham 1-1 Crystal Palace (Woodrow) The teenager Cauley Woodrow has scored his first Premier League goal, and Carl Jenkinson has scored his first senior goal.
 16.16 Reality is starting to sink in at Anfield.  At the Etihad, Demichelis is booked for ploughing through both ball and Mark Noble.
 GOAL!  Sunderland 1-1 Manchester United (Mata); West Brom 1-1 Stoke (Sessegnon) A couple of equalisers: a wonderful free-kick from Juan Mata, and a calm finish from Stephane Sessegnon.
 Twitter: Henry Winter - Huge Poznan at #mcfc .... party fully underway
GOAL!  Norwich 0-1 Arsenal (Ramsey); Sunderland 1-3 Swansea (Bony) Aaron Ramsey gives Arsenal the lead with a fine goal at Norwich, his 15th goal of a frustratingly incomplete season, while Sunderland are back in the metaphorical pub having got back to 2-1 for a couple of minutes.
 16.07 As things stand there has been a 14-point swing between City and Liverpool since April 20, although City did have two games in hand.
 GOAL!  Sunderland 1-2 Swansea (Borini)
GOAL!  Manchester City 2-0 West Ham (Kompany) A few weeks ago, we thought Vincent Kompany had given the title to Liverpool.  Now he has sealed it for Manchester City, lashing home gleefully from a yards when a corner was not properly cleared.
 GOAL!  Hull City 0-2 Everton (Lukaku) Romalu Lukaku has scored in what might be his last game for the club.  Hull are in desperate form going into the FA Cup final.  This is sometimes a problem with Steve Bruce sides; he overachieves by keeping them up comfortably, but then they have nothing to play for in the last month or two of the season.
 16.02 Manchester City's second half in underway, and Liverpool are about to kick off at Anfield.  If Liverpool win the title from here, the Michael Thomas and Sergio Aguero seasons will almost seem like comfortable formalities by comparison.
 15.57 Here's Nemanja Vidic, in his final game, putting a new spin of the idea of a claret-and-blue kit.
 15.50 It's half time in all the Premier League games now.  The latest scores are above.  And this is the Premier League table as things stand.
 15.46 Silva hits the post!  It was a low shot from a tight angle that took a deflection and flew onto the far post.  City could have scored three of four in the last 10 minutes of the first half.  No matter: they are well on course for the title.  It's half time there, and at Anfield.  It will take some unprecedented Cityitis for this to go wrong now.
 15.45 Paul Merson describes Manchester United's performance at Southampton as "shocking, embarrassing".  Moyes out!
15.44 Another chance for City, with Zabaleta's close-range shot deflected wide from Aguero's dangerous low cross.  It's all City now.  How must poor Steven Gerrard feel?  One simple lapse in concentration while doing a short pass on the turn, the kind of thing he has done thousands of times in his career, may have cost him the thing he craved most.
 Twitter: Henry Winter - Zabaleta's phenomenal, defending one moment, almost getting on the end of a sweeping move the next.  #mcfc
15.41 As half-time approaches, West Ham are hanging on bravely to their 1-0 deficit, with nine men behind the ball.  Aguero flicks a header across goal and wide from a right-wing free kick.
 15.40 Daniel Sturridge has missed a wonderful chance, flicking a header across goal and wide from seven yards.
 GOAL!  Manchester City 1-0 West Ham (Nasri) That should be the title for City!  Samir Nasri has given them the lead with a low 20-yard shot across goal that Adrian could only palm into the corner.  It now needs a four-goal swing - two at the Etihad, two at Anfield - to deny City their second title in three seasons.
 Twitter: Paul Hayward - Man City-West Ham now looks exactly like Man City-Aston Villa in midweek.  A passing and prodding exercise.
 GOAL!  Spurs 3-0 Aston Villa (Adebayor pen) A comical handball from Agbonlahor gives Spurs a penalty, and Emmanuel Adebayor scores.
 GOAL!  Fulham 0-1 Crystal Palace (Gayle); Spurs 2-0 Aston Villa (Baker own goal) Another goal for Dwight Gayle, who scored two against Liverpool on Monday, while Spurs have clinched a Europa League place thanks to the third own goal of the day, this one from Villa's Nathan Baker.
 15.34 Another chance for Liverpool, with Suarez shooting tamely at Krul from the end of the area after a fine run.
 15.32 Silva almost wriggles through for City, but West Ham managed to crowd him out and concede a corner.
 15.31 Kevin Nolan is booked for an oafish challenge of Joe Hart.
 15.30 Nemanja Vidic is bleeding profusely on the touchline at St Mary's, having been caught on the nose by Lambert in the build-up to the goal.  Paul Merson, on Sky, says Vidic is furious and may be looking to serve up a particularly cold dish.
 15.28 If West Ham played 19th century football at Chelsea, then they've gone back in time to the 17th century for this game.  They often have nine men in their own area, but it's working because Adiran has had very little to do.  If I were a City fan, I'd be getting slightly nervous.
 15.27 It's Liverpool at home to Newcastle, and it could easily end 4-3 given the quality of Liverpool's attacking and the ineptitude of their defending.
 GOAL!  Southampton 1-0 Manchester United (Lambert) The team of the season take a richly deserved lead at St Mary's, and Rickie Lambert perhaps seals a World Cup place with a classy finish in front of Roy Hodgson.
 15.26 Mignolet makes a fine save from Gouffran, who galloped through on goal after a beautiful, slick move from Newcastle.  That should have been 2-0.
 Twitter: Luke Edwards - #safc are playing like a team that secured their PL safety on Wednesday night and celebrated the fact with a lot of drinking
15.25 City have had Guardiola levels of possession, yet they are struggling to penetrate as much as they would like so Kolarov tries a ludicrous shot from 40 yards that Adrian leaps to tip over the bar.  It was probably going over anyway.
 15.23 Agger has missed a great chance for Liverpool, planting a header too close to Krul from seven yards.
 GOAL!  West Brom 0-1 Stoke City (McAuley own goal) Stoke's excellent season looks like it may end on a high, and they seem set to exceed their highest Premier League points total.
 15.21 That goal isn't a huge problem for Liverpool, not this early in the day.  If they need to win this game by scoring two goals in the last 10 minutes, they will.  City showed that two years ago when they scored two in injury-time.  For Liverpool it's far more important, at this early stage, that Manchester City don't go ahead.
 GOAL!  Liverpool 0-1 Newcastle (Skrtel own goal) And now Newcastle lead!  Moments after that Suarez effort, Martin Skrtel shinned a cross from the left over Mignolet and into the far corner.  It's his fourth own goal of the season, a Premier League record.
 15.17 Luis Suarez has just had a sensational goal disallowed.  He won a free-kick wide on the right, bounced to his feet and raked a glorious, quick-witted effort over Krul with the outside of his right foot before anyone else knew what was happening.  It even caught the cameraman out.  But the referee Phil Dowd disallowed it, presumably because he hadn't blown the whistle, although I'm not certain as I have approximately 47 different screens open at the moment.
 GOAL!  Cardiff 1-0 Chelsea (Bellamy) Craig Bellamy's deflected shot has put Cardiff ahead.
 GOAL!  Tottenham 1-0 Aston Villa (Paulinho) Bad news for Spurs fans: Paulinho has given them the lead and they now almost certain of a Europa League place.
 GOAL!  Sunderland 0-2 Swansea (Emnes) A fine goal from Marvin Emnes has put Swansea 2-0 up against Sunderland, whose heads may or may not be on the beach/in the pub.
15.11 A really good chance for David Silva, who wallops a volley miles over the bar from eight yards.  A rare moment of technical imperfection from him which is matched seconds later by Nolan; he lines one up from 25 yards and drives it approximately 500 yards over the bar.
 GOAL!  Hull City 0-1 Everton (McCarthy) James McCarthy gets his first Everton goal to continue their wonderful improvement under Roberto Martinez, who has single-handedly taken them from sixth last season to fifth this.
 15.09 City have an appeal turned down when Mark Noble miskicks a clearance onto his own hand.  His hand was outstretched but it was surely accidental.  At Anfield, Shola Ameobi clambers over a defender only to head straight at Mignolet from eight yards.
 GOAL!  Sunderland 0-1 Swansea (Dyer) Nathan Dyer has given Swansea a lead, while Southampton have been denied an apparently clear penalty after a handball by Nemanja Vidic.  Mike Dean declined to give the decision, which is particularly strange given his love of sticking his derriere out and pointing theatrically at the spot.
 15.06 Oscar has missed another fine chance for Chelsea at Cardiff.  Chelsea could still finish second in the table, though that would take Newcastle to get something at Anfield.
 15.05 At Cardiff, Steven Caulker has cleared off the line from Fernando Torres, while Shola Ameobi had headed a third-chance wide from 12 yards at Anfield.
 15.04 Three minutes gone, and no incidents of note at the Etihad or Anfield.  Meanwhile, could somebody please show this picture to Roy Keane and video his reaction?  Ta.
 15.00 Peep peep!  The 10 games are under way and, er, that's about all there is to say.
 14.58 City's players are going through the contemporary pre-match routine of zestful high-fiving.  At Anfield, the atmosphere is one of proud defiance.  You'd expect Liverpool to wallop Newcastle today.
 Twitter: Mark Ogden - Man City clearly trying to jinx themselves by having Georgi Kinkladze as guest of honour today...
14.55 In other news, the best midfielder on Manchester United's payroll prepares for the match at Southampton.
 14.50 One of the truths that dare not speak their name about the Premier League is that the final day is usually quite dull, certainly in terms of the title race.  Only three have gone to the final minute of the final game - 1994-95, 1998-99 and of course the Aguerooooooooooooooooo moment of 2011-12.  Maybe Martin Tyler will shout "Carrolllllllllll!" at a similar juncture today as he wins the title for Liverpool by roofing one from 30 yards.
 14.45 Imaginary Opta stats tell us there is a 94.21 per cent chance that the phrase "Squeaky Bum Time" will be used today.  Here's Thom Gibbs to give you, er, chapter and verse on that particular phrase.
 Damian Durrant: "Why does a City win feel like such a let down?  The City team could be anywhere from Sydney to Qatar, they don't actually have any connection to Manchester.. .  Its no more than gladiator games with foreign talent.  The richest team won again.  Somehow, a Liverpool win doesn't feel so empty." "
I know what you mean, although that's not City's fault.  But yes, in 50 years' time we might look back at 2013-14 as the last time a team came from nowhere to challenge for the English league without spending a grotesque amount of money.  (Even if Liverpool have spent a bit more than most people think.) )
14.25 Could somebody please show this picture to Roy Keane and send me a video of his reaction?  Ta.
 Twitter: Henry Winter - Pellegrini in programme on #mcfc playing with "style & flair.  Football is an entertainment business.  It's what our supporters demand" #whufc
14.20 And here are the teams in the other matches.
 Cardiff v Chelsea
Cardiff Marshall, Fabio, Caulker, Turner, John; Gunnarsson, Mutch, Whittingham, Daehli, Bellamy, Campbell.
 Chelsea Schwarzer, Azpilicueta, Ivanovic, Kalas, Cole, Mikel, Matic, Salah, Oscar, Hazard, Torres.
 Fulham v Crystal Palace
Fulham Stockdale, Zverotić, Heitinga, Hangeland, Amorebieta, Kačaniklić, Sidwell, Parker, Richardson, Rodallega, Woodrow.
 Crystal Palace Hennessey, Mariappa, Dann, Delaney, Ward, Bolasie, Jedinak, Ledley, Ince, Chamakh, Gayle.
 Hull City v Everton
Hull City McGregor, Figueroa, Bruce, Davies, Huddlestone, Livermore, McShane, Jelavic, Aluko, Elmohamady, Quinn.
 Everton Howard, Baines, Coleman, Jagielka, Distin, McGeady, Naismith, McCarthy, Lukaku, Barry, Osman
Norwich City v Arsenal
Norwich City Ruddy, Martin, R Bennett, Turner, Olsson; Tettey, Snodgrass, Howson, Johnson, Redmond, Elmander.
 Arsenal Fabianski, Jenkinson, Sagna, Koscielny, Gibbs, Arteta, Rosicky, Ramsey, Ozil, Podolski, Giroud.
 Southampton v Manchester United
Southampton Boruc, Clyne, Fonte, Lovren, Shaw, Wanyama, Cork, Schneiderlin, Davis, Lallana, Lambert.
 Manchester United De Gea, Smalling, Ferdinand, Vidic, Evra, Januzaj, Fletcher, Kagawa, Welbeck, Mata, van Persie.
 Sunderland v Swansea City
Sunderland Mannone, Vergini, Bardsley, Brown, O'Shea, Bridcutt, Larsson, Colback, Johnson, Borini, Wickham.
 Swansea City Tremmel, Tiendalli, Amat, Bartley, Taylor, Fulton, Shelvey, Dyer, Emnes, Routledge, Bony.
 Tottenham Hotspur v Aston Villa
Tottenham Hotspur Lloris, Naughton, Chiriches, Dawson, Rose, Sandro; Sigurdsson, Paulinho, Eriksen, Adebayor, Kane.
 Aston Villa Guzan, Lowton, Vlaar, Baker, Bertrand, Bacuna, Westwood, Delph, Weimann, Bowery, Agbonlahor.
 West Brom v Stoke
West Brom Foster, Dawson, McAuley, Olsson, Brunt, Dorrans, Mulumbu, Morrison, Amalfitano, Sessegnon, Berahino.
 Stoke Sorensen, Muniesa, Shawcross, Wilson, Cameron, Arnautovic, Whelan, Nzonzi, Odemwingie, Ireland, Walters.
 14.05 Here are the teams in the two big matches at the top of the table.
 Manchester City v West Ham
Manchester City Hart, Zabaleta, Kompany, Demichelis, Kolarov, Garcia, Toure, Nasri, Silva, Aguero, Dzeko.
 West Ham Adrian, Reid, McCartney, Nolan, Tomkins, Carroll, Taylor, Noble, O'Brien, Diame, Downing.
 Liverpool v Newcastle
Liverpool Mignolet, Johnson, Skrtel, Agger, Flanagan, Henderson, Gerrard, Allen, Sterling, Suarez, Sturridge.
 Newcastle Krul, S.Taylor, Williamson, Coloccini, Haidara, Debuchy, Anita, Tiote, Gouffran, Sissoko, Shola Ameobi.
 14.00 We'll have some team news any second now.  Meantime, here's the scene at the Etihad.  Even allowing for decades of Cityitis, surely Manhester City won't blow this today?
13.40 Rob Smyth Understands™ that John Terry and Frank Lampard have not travelled to Cardiff with the Chelsea squad.
 (When I say Rob Smyth Understands, I mean that Jeff Stelling just said as much on Sky Sports News.  Either way, there's a chance it might be the end of Chelsea's greatest era.) )
13.36 Thanks to Phil Podolsky for pointing out that today is the 30th birthday of the world's most beautiful footballer.
 13.31 Oh, and here's the goal of the season, since you asked politely.
 13.30 Roy Hodgson would have loved to be at Anfield, ideally on the Kop, in case Liverpool win the title, but he has selflessly put Queen and Country first by having one last look at the Southampton Collective.  Adam Lallana is a shoo-in for Brazil, but Luke Shaw and Rickie Lambert remain borderline selections.  For whatever it's worth (clue: absolutely nowt), I'd take Lambert but not Shaw.
 Twitter: Telegraph Football - Richard Scudamore will not review his position after apologising for emails which contained sexist remarks http://t.co/b5gk6Juvf3
Phil Podolsky: "Another No1 from the season - the saddest cultural fact from Cameron's Britain: Gerrard coming ahead of Toure in the football writers' poll.  Journalists are supposed to be reasonably intelligent grown-ups, not the blinkered types you typically encounter on football blogs, or people stuck in the grip of nationalistic fervour." "
The cult of the English superstar (sic) is a fascinating thing, and a problem that permeates the entire English game.  See also the weird perception that Wayne Rooney has had a good season.. .
 12.55 Here's Marytn Denney from Easy Odds to satisfy all your bookmakerly needs.
 "Just three weeks ago, Manchester City trailed Liverpool by seven points and leading odds comparison site easyodds.com can reveal that Manuel Pellegrini's side were as long as 6/1 for the title.  Now, needing just one point to clinch the crown, City are as short as 1/40.  Liverpool are 19/1 for their first title since 1990, they were 1/16 to win the league back in mid-April." "
Those odds suggest the full Devon Loch from Liverpool, though they were never more than one bad result away from ceding the initiative.  Does it really compare to the two big collapses of the Premier League era, Newcastle 1995-96 and Manchester United 2011-12?  We'll have a better idea once the dust settles.  And you never know: they might, like Manchester City in 2011-12, end up both bottling the title and winning it.
 12.50 City and Liverpool aside, it's an unusually quiet final day, with very little to play for.  The relegation battle is all but decided, with Norwich needing snookers, while Manchester United look set to beat Tottenham in the battle to stay out of the Europa League.  The upshot of that is that we should have loads of goals - with so little play for, there should be a jaunty end-of-term feel, in which hundreds of grown men get to become little boys again and experience the oldfangled sensation that football can actually be fun.  There's nobody on the touchline shouting at them to TRACK THE BLOODY THIRD-MAN RUN or TUCK IN AS A FALSE 7.5.  They can just enjoy themselves.
 12.45 Feel free to email in with your highlights of the season, or anything else.  Here are three to start off with.
 12.30 The games kick off at 3pm today, as has been the norm since the last round of fixtures were moved to a Sunday in 1994-95 (Wimbledon v Nottm Forest excepted, for some reason).
 Twitter: Paul Hayward - Some No1s from this season.  Manager - Pulis.  Team - Liverpool.  Footballer - Suarez.  Celebration - Eto'o, old man.  Over-used word - moment.
 Twitter: Paul Hayward - Leader by example - Yaya Toure.  Free-spirit - Lallana.  AWOL - Lamela.  80s retro rage - Sherwood.  Self-harm - Fulham.  Youngster - Sterling.
 12.00 Hello.  The Premier League version of Pass the Parcel is played with different rules.  The winner is the person who is holding the parcel when the music stops.  The parcel has changed hands 25 times in the 2013-14 version, and the music is set to stop at around 4.52pm today.  Twenty-five changes of leadership, from the moment Manchester city leapfrogged Manchester United on August 19.  David Moyes got to be a Premier League leader for only a couple of days.
 City have actually only been top of the league for 14 days, primarily because they had games in hand for most of the campaign due to postponed fixtures.  Arsenal led the table for longest, 128 days, before their sadly predictable regression to the mean of fourth place, where they have finished for six of the last nine seasons.  Chelsea and particularly Liverpool had periods where they seemed in control of the title race, and Liverpool will hope the parcel changes hands for the 26th time at some stage today.
 It doesn't seem likely.  Almost everyone expects City to secure the necessary point against Sam Allardyce's intrepid 19th-century blunderers, not least because City marmalised West Ham 6-0 in the League Cup semi-final first leg at the Etihad in January.  Then again one last, absurd twist - Andy Carroll winning the title for Liverpool with a goal off his freshly waxed derriere, perhaps - might be a more appropriate end to perhaps the most doolally English title race since 1971-72.
 10.00 Rob Smyth will be here from midday with all the build-up to what should be an action-packed final day of the Premier League season.
 In the meantime, here is Greg Dyke's somewhat contentious view on who he wants to win the title race this afternoon...
 Greg Dyke, the FA chairman, has said it would be "pretty depressing" if Manchester City won the title with so few English players in their side.  City have to avoid defeat at home to West Ham United to guarantee finishing ahead of Liverpool and claim the title for the second time in three years.
 Dyke, whose FA Commission into the future of English football published its report last week to a hostile reception, said: "It's been a great league this year.  But, if there is only one England player, maybe two [in City's team], that's pretty depressing.  I think the figures that we produced showed the top four averaged 29 [English players between them] and this year it is down to 24 - we should be worried about that." "
And here is Kevin Nolan on why Liverpool can win the Premier League...
 He may not have endeared himself to his boyhood club when he was handed a red card at Anfield for a nasty stamp on Jordan Henderson in December but, all of a sudden, Kevin Nolan finds himself the most popular man on Merseyside.
 "I've had lots of texts this week and more messages from Liverpool fans than ever before," the West Ham United captain said.  "My brother is on Twitter and he's had lots of messages this week saying, 'If he could do us a favour, it would be great' and, 'We'll give him this' and, 'We'll give him that'." "
results.title: Premier League final day 2014: as it happened

results.body:
Blue and white ticker tape filled the air and fans poured on to the pitch at the final whistle as City, who only needed a draw to win the trophy, finished two points clear of Liverpool whose campaign ended with a 2-1 win over Newcastle United.
 Samir Nasri calmed City nerves by drilling them ahead in 39th minute, and captain Vincent Kompany's neat finish four minutes after halftime put the hosts in cruise control, rounding off a superb debut season for manager Manuel Pellegrini.
 "It's an amazing feeling.  My second title in three years.  It was an amazing league the whole year," Frenchman Nasri told Sky Sports.  "There are no words to explain my feelings now." "
For Chilean Pellegrini, it was a first league title since he won the Clausura with River Plate in Argentina in 2003, and his first title in Europe.
 "I'm just so happy for the manager as well because it's his first title in Europe, it's amazing," Nasri added.
 The atmosphere at Anfield was muted as an own goal from Martin Skrtel put Newcastle ahead in the first half, but goals from Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge ensured they ended with victory against opponents who had Shola Ameobi and Paul Dummett sent off.
 Chelsea had to settle for third spot after coming from a goal down to win 2-1 at Cardiff City, ending a trophyless first season back in England for manager Jose Mourinho.
 Tottenham Hotspur comfortably beat Aston Villa 3-0 to finish sixth and clinch a place in next season's Europa League, meaning former champions Manchester United, who drew their final match of a terrible season 1-1 against Southampton, will not play in Europe next season for the first time in 24 years.
 Norwich City's relegation was confirmed with a 2-0 home defeat by Arsenal and they will join Cardiff and Fulham in the Championship next season.
results.title: Man City beat West Ham 2-0 to win Premier League title

results.body:
Manchester, England (SportsNetwork.c com) - Manchester City claimed its second Premier League title in three years by getting a 2-0 win over West Ham United at the Etihad on Sunday.
 The Citizens, who famously clinched the title in 2012 thanks to a last-gasp winner from Sergio Aguero, secured the top spot in the table in slightly less dramatic fashion, controlling West Ham on home soil and collecting three points behind goals from Samir Nasri and Vincent Kompany.
 City was held in check until the 39th minute when Nasri received a pass from Yaya Toure and fired a right-footed shot off the post and into the back of the net.
 Kompany doubled City's advantage just four minutes into the second half, pouncing on a loose ball inside the six-yard box and poking home from close range to seal the win.
 The performance capped City's best-ever season in the top flight as Manuel Pellegrini's men finished on 86 points, scoring 102 goals and conceding just 37.
 West Ham enjoyed a late surge this season to avoid relegation, finishing the campaign with 40 points.
 Liverpool 2, Newcastle 1
Liverpool, England - Liverpool ensured a second-place finish on Sunday thanks to a 2-1 defeat of Newcastle United at Anfield.
 The Reds, who needed Manchester City to lose against West Ham in order to have any realistic shot at the title, dug themselves into a hole when they conceded the lead behind an own goal from Martin Skrtel in the 20th minute.
 Liverpool managed to get the victory thanks to goals from Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge two minutes apart, but City's victory over the Hammers meant that the Reds would be made to finish the season two points back of top spot with 84 points on the season.
 Tottenham 3, Aston Villa 0
London, England - Tottenham secured a place in the Europa League next season by getting a 3-0 win over Aston Villa at White Hart Lane.
 Spurs netted all three goals in the first of half of Sunday's affair.  Paulinho opened the scoring in the 14th minute before a 35th-minute own goal from Nathan Baker and a penalty from Emmanuel Adebayor three minutes later sealed the victory.
 Tottenham finishes the season in sixth place on 69 points while Villa finishes sixth from bottom on 38 points.
 Swansea City 3, Sunderland 1
Sunderland, England - Swansea City closed out its Premier League season with an emphatic 3-1 victory over Sunderland at the Stadium of Light on Sunday.
 Goals from Nathan Dyer and Marvin Emnes inside the opening 14 minutes put visiting Swansea in the driver's seat early on.
 Fabio Borini pulled one back for Sunderland in the 50th minute, but Wilfried Bony responded four minutes later to see the Swans finish the season on a high note.
 Manchester United 1, Southampton 1
Southampton, England - Manchester United avoided defeat in its final match of the season, coming from behind to get a point from a 1-1 draw at Southampton on Sunday.
 The Saints were in front after 28 minutes when Rickie Lambert got through on goal to slip a shot past David De Gea, but Juan Mata brought the Red Devils level in the 54th minute by curling a superb free kick into the upper corner.
results.title: Manchester City tops West Ham to clinch Premier League title
