results.title: EPL PHOTOS: City stay calm to clinch second title in three years

results.body:
There was no call for last-gasp heroics as Manchester City claimed the Premier League with a comfortable 2-0 victory over West Ham United at the Etihad Stadium.
 City had famously relied on two injury-time goals when beating Manchester United to the title on goal difference in 2012, but this time around Samir Nasri broke the deadlock six minutes before the break before Vincent Kompany settled the nerves on 49 minutes.
 City had gone into the game knowing a draw was almost certainly enough to secure the title as a result of their goal difference.
 Liverpool battled back from a Martin Skrtel own goal to defeat Newcastle United 2-1 at Anfield.
 Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge scored in the 63rd and 65th minutes, and Newcastle then saw both Shola Ameobi and Paul Dummett sent off, but City's victory ended any prospect of a long-awaited 19th league title for the Reds.
results.title: Prem: City crowned champions, Norwich down

results.body:
The Blue Moon eclipsed the Red Machine on the final day of the season to claim the 2013/14 Premier League title, putting in a commanding performance at home to West Ham United to win 2-0.
 City needed only a point to clinch their second league title in three campaigns, but victory was rarely in doubt at the Etihad Stadium, as top spot was secured in far less dramatic circumstances than two years ago.
 This time round City were coasting at 2-0 up with most of the second half to play, which - combined with Liverpool trailing Newcastle for an hour at Anfield - served to dissipate any nerves in the blue half of Manchester.
 While City had ended a 44-year wait for the title in 2012, down the East Lancs Road, Liverpool fans started the day still dreaming of a first league championship in 24 years, but it was always hopeful relying on the Hammers to take three points at the Etihad.
 Instead, Brendan Rodgers' team had to console themselves with a 2-1 comeback win against the Magpies and what is, on reflection, a surprising second place finish for a side that had ended last year 28 points off top spot, compared to a two-point deficit on City this time round.
 If there was to be a shock finale, you felt that Liverpool needed to score early and maybe, just maybe the score and any possible nerves might be transmitted to the Etihad crowd, and possibly players.
 City were calm and composed in dismissing Aston Villa 4-0 earlier in the week to go top, and they began with the same composure that was undoubtedly aided by the knowledge that a draw would suffice for top spot.
 At Anfield the Reds have made a habit of blowing teams away early on, and after 10 minutes their impressive England youngster Raheem Sterling was played in, but hit a tame shot at goal under pressure as the referee waved away his team-mate's penalty appeals.
 The Premier League Player of the Year, Luis Suarez, was clearly desperate to end the season on a high and was his usual hard working self, flying around the pitch as Liverpool looked to turn up the pressure.
 Suarez appeared to have given his team a stunning lead on 19 minutes, taking a free-kick from an audacious angle, wide on the right, chipping the ball over a stranded Tim Krul in the Newcastle goal, only for it to be disallowed for being taken from the wrong position.
 As if to confirm that it wasn't to be Liverpool's day, a minute later Martin Skrtel contrived to deflect a cross in to the his own goal and deflate Kopite hopes that the improbable could be achieved.
 Meanwhile, at the Etihad Stadium, City were piling on the pressure against Sam Allardyce's stubborn, but uninspired West Ham.
 Flying full-back Aleksandr Kolarov let fly from 30 yards, forcing Hammers goalkeeper Adrian to turn over at full stretch, and it was all City as news of Skrtel's own goal filtered through to the Manchester crowd.
 Back at Anfield, the recalled Daniel Agger nearly forced an equaliser with a header that Tim Krul stopped on the line, but after being caught on the break by Chelsea and Crystal Palace in the two results that ultimately did for their title dreams, Liverpool were again living dangerously.
 On 26 minutes, Newcastle's Gouffran was played clean through the middle, with only Simon Mignolet to beat.  The Belgian stood tall and the Kop breathed a sigh of relief.
 Gouffran was duly played in again two minutes later, only for Glen Johnson to this time snuff out the danger.
 Nevertheless, it served to highlight the reason that this Liverpool team have fallen agonisingly short of the standard set by champions City.
 Then, on 38 minutes at the Etihad Stadium, Samir Nasri put the champions-elect one up with a hard and low right-foot shot, palmed in to the bottom corner by Adrian, sparking scenes of jubilation in Manchester as the City players and fans knew the trophy was nearly in the bag.
 City hit the bar with a shot from Silva on the stroke of half-time, and with Liverpool going in 1-0 down it seemed that only a miracle, not Andy Carroll, could turn things on its head.
 That feeling grew stronger still when City's popular captain Vincent Kompany pounced in the six yard box just three minutes in the second half to thrash home a knockdown and symbolically seal the title, with City's 102nd goal of the Premier League season.
 With the title race now done and dusted, there remained the possibility that Liverpool could yet finish third in a two-horse, if they fell to defeat and Chelsea won at Cardiff City.
 That would have been harsh on the Reds after a season in which their phenomenal goal scoring exploits have been second only to City's impressive attacking, and just after the hour at Anfield, Steven Gerrard whipped in a free-kick from the right, which Daniel Agger turned in at the Kop end to level things.
 After toiling for an equaliser, it took just 60 seconds for Liverpool to go ahead, with another Gerrard set piece delivered to the back post, this time for Daniel Sturridge to steer home the Reds' 101st goal of the league campaign.
 It was a fitting consolation for Liverpool, who saw out the game comfortably after Newcastle's Shola Ameobi saw red, picking up a second yellow for arguing with the referee, while team-mate Paul Dummett also got sent off for a tackle on Suarez.
 However, in the final equation Manchester City were just too good for the Reds and the rest of the Premier League.
 While there wasn't the drama of 2012 in City's title-winning match this time, the scenes of jubilation in Manchester as the final whistle went confirmed that this victory tasted sweet indeed.
 In his first season as a City manager, Manuel Pellegrini has delivered a title win and the League Cup, just as Jose Mourinho did in his first year as Chelsea boss.
 The new Special One and everyone connected with City will rightly savour success in what has been a special Premier League season.
results.title: Manchester City win the Premier League title and break Liverpool hearts

results.body:
Russell Martin: Waves goodbye to the Premier League with Norwich
Sky Bet Loading Market ...  Football Betting Up To £30 Free Matched Bet
Manchester City wrapped up a second Premier League title in three seasons after beating West Ham United after Liverpool's come-from-behind win over Newcastle United proved to be in vain.
 Norwich City's relegation from the top flight was confirmed after a home defeat by fourth-placed Arsenal, while Tottenham Hotspur booked Europa League football for next season by beating Aston Villa.
 A look back at the best bits from this season's Soccer Saturday with Jeff and the boys.
 Ryan Giggs' likely last game as Manchester United manager ended in a draw at Southampton, as FA Cup finalists Hull City were beaten at home by Everton.
 Bottom club Cardiff City bowed out of the Premier League with a home defeat by Chelsea as fellow relegated side Fulham twice came from behind to draw with Crystal Palace.
 Stoke City recorded their highest Premier League finish with a win at out-of-form West Bromwich Albion and Sunderland's recent flying run was checked by Swansea City.
 Click below for individual match reports and stats:
Cardiff 1 Chelsea 2
Fulham 2 C Palace 2
Hull City 0 Everton 2
Liverpool 2 Newcastle 1
Man City 2 West Ham 0
Norwich 0 Arsenal 2
Southampton 1 Man Utd 1
Sunderland 1 Swansea 3
Tottenham 3 Aston Villa 0
West Brom 1 Stoke 2
Samir Nasri and Vincent Kompany scored the goals as Manchester City beat West Ham 2-0 at the Etihad Stadium to claim the title by two points.
 City were rarely troubled by the visitors in the first half and took the lead on 39 minutes when goalkeeper Adrian lacked a strong enough hand to keep out Nasri's dipping 25-yard drive.
 Manuel Pellegrini's side almost scored a second in stoppage-time when David Silva's shot deflected off Andy Carroll and struck the crossbar.
 Vincent Kompany lifts the Premier League trophy after Manchester City sealed the title with a 2-0 win over West Ham.
 The second goal came four minutes after half-time when a corner deflected into Kompany's path and the defender finished from close range to ensure City secured the title in Pellegrini's first season as manager.
 Liverpool came from behind to round off their excellent season with a 2-1 home win over Newcastle, who finished the match with nine men.
 Liverpool fell behind in the 20th minute when Yoan Gouffran got down the left-hand side and his cross was shinned into his own net by defender Martin Skrtel.
 Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers gives his thoughts after his side finished second in the Premier League.
 Gouffran should have then made it 2-0 when he was sent clear, but his shot was well saved by Simon Mignolet before Liverpool striker Daniel Sturridge headed wide when picked out unmarked in the box.
 Brendan Rodgers' side equalised on 63 minutes when Steven Gerrard's free-kick from the right was steered home by Daniel Agger at the far post.
 Just two minutes later, Liverpool took the lead in almost identical fashion as Gerrard whipped in another free-kick from a similar position, but this time it was Sturridge at the back post to score from close range.
 And, before the game could restart, Newcastle striker Shola Ameobi was sent off after being booked twice in quick succession by referee Phil Dowd for dissent.
 Newcastle were reduced to nine men with three minutes to go when Paul Dummett was sent off just five minutes after coming on as a substitute following a collision with Luis Suarez.
 Norwich's relegation from the Premier League was confirmed after Arsenal warmed up for next week's FA Cup final against Hull City with a 2-0 win at Carrow Road.
 Arsene Wenger is pleased to have an FA Cup final selection headache with Aaron Ramsey, Jack Wilshere and Abou Diaby back from injury.
 Arsenal edged in front in stunning fashion on 53 minutes when Olivier Giroud crossed from the left to the far post where Aaron Ramsey volleyed first time beyond John Ruddy into the top corner.
 Arsene Wenger's side added a second goal nine minutes later when Kieran Gibbs' cut-back bounced into the path of Carl Jenkinson and the full-back side-footed home his first Arsenal goal with the aid of a deflection.
 West Brom's 2-1 home defeat by Stoke proved to matter little to the hosts following Norwich's defeat, but the result ensured a ninth-placed finish for Mark Hughes' side.
 Stoke were handed the advantage midway through the first half in fortunate fashion when Marko Arnautovic's pull-back was turned into his own net by Gareth McAuley, who was running back towards his own goal.
 West Brom equalised on 56 minutes when Stephane Sessegnon, who hit the crossbar after just three minutes, swept home Craig Dawson's cross.
 But Stoke clinched a fifth successive win at The Hawthorns with three minutes to go when Charlie Adam drove an angled left-footed effort from 25 yards beyond the dive of Ben Foster.
 A 3-0 victory over Aston Villa at White Hart Lane, in what could be Tim Sherwood's last match as manager, guaranteed European football for Tottenham next season.
 Tim Sherwood says he's enjoyed his time in management and would like to continue but is unsure if it will be at Tottenham.
 Tottenham took the lead on 14 minutes when the ball broke kindly into Paulinho's path and, after his initial shot was parried by Brad Guzan, the Brazil international scored from the rebound.
 There was an element of fortune about Spurs' second goal on 35 minutes when Danny Rose's driven cross brushed Emmanuel Adebayor before deflecting past Guzan off Nathan Baker.
 And three minutes later, Spurs made it 3-0 when Adebayor blasted home a penalty after Sandro's shot had struck Gabriel Agbonlahor on the arm.
 Last season's champions Manchester United closed the door on a disappointing campaign with a seventh-placed finish following a 1-1 draw against eighth-placed Southampton at St Mary's.
 Southampton went in front in the 28th minute when Rickie Lambert collected Steven Davis' pass to score, although United were unhappy after the England international's flailing elbow left Nemanja Vidic with a bloodied face.
 United drew level nine minutes into the second half when record signing Juan Mata curled a 25-yard free-kick over the wall and into the top corner.
 Chelsea scored twice in the space of three second-half minutes to beat relegated Cardiff 2-1 in south Wales.
 Cardiff forged in front on the quarter-hour mark when Craig Bellamy's 25-yard effort took a wicked deflection off Cesar Azpilicueta on its way past Mark Schwarzer.
 Jose Mourinho admits he's pleased with Chelsea's comeback after seeing his team win 2-1 at Cardiff.
 Chelsea levelled on 72 minutes when substitute Andre Schurrle fired home the loose ball after Azpilicueta had first been denied by David Marshall and then the crossbar.
 Just three minutes later, Chelsea were in front when Schurrle's header found an onside Fernando Torres and the Spain striker had a simple finish past Marshall.
 Romelu Lukaku marked the final appearance of his loan spell at Everton with a goal as Roberto Martinez's men beat Hull City 2-0 at the KC Stadium.
 Romelu Lukaku says his loan spell at Everton has improved him.
 A well-worked goal put Everton ahead on nine minutes when Lukaku and Steven Naismith combined to play in James McCarthy and the midfielder's shot struck the hands of fit-again Hull keeper Allan McGregor on its way into the net.
 Everton increased their lead in the opening minute of the second half via another fine move which ended with Leon Osman slipping a pass through to Lukaku, who curled his shot past McGregor.
 Dwight Gayle twice put Crystal Palace in front at Craven Cottage before Chris David scored a stoppage-time equaliser as Fulham dropped into the Championship with a 2-2 draw.
 Felix Magath admits there will be a summer of change at the club after their relegation from the Premier League.
 Palace took the lead on 28 minutes when Gayle, who scored twice in Monday's thrilling 3-3 draw with Liverpool, diverted Joel Ward's shot beyond David Stockdale.
 Fulham levelled in the 61st minute when young striker Cauley Woodrow cut inside before curling a shot past Wayne Hennessey for his first goal for the club.
 But Palace were back in front with six minutes to go when the in-form Gayle whipped a 25-yard free-kick around the wall and beyond Stockdale.
 Felix Magath's side did provide their fans with a final flourish as, in the third minute of added time, David cut inside and thumped a shot in off the bar.
 Garry Monk marked his first game since being named Swansea's permanent manager with a 3-1 win over Sunderland at the Stadium of Light.
 Swansea went ahead after just seven minutes when Wayne Routledge's superb slide-rule pass played in Nathan Dyer and he clipped his shot over Vito Mannone.
 The visitors doubled their lead on 14 minutes when Marvin Emnes turned sharply on the edge of the box from Wilfried Bony's pass and lashed a shot past Mannone.
 Sunderland pulled a goal back five minutes into the second half when on-loan striker Fabio Borini marked his final appearance by heading home a corner.
 But Swansea restored their two-goal cushion four minutes later when Emnes' cross deflected out to Bony and his low shot went in via the post.
results.title: Premier League round-up

results.body:
Manchester City rubber-stamped their second Barclays Premier League title in three years with a 2-0 win over West Ham, while Norwich's relegation was finally confirmed as the 2013-14 season finished on Sunday.
 Unusually for this topsy-turvy year, everything pretty much went as expected at both ends of the table.
 City knew all they needed was a draw, due to their two-point gap and superior goal difference over second-placed Liverpool.
 The Reds beat Newcastle 2-1 but it was of little consequence, while Norwich limped to a 2-0 defeat to Arsenal as they were relegated to the Sky Bet Championship.
 It was a nervy opening at Eastlands, but as news filtered through of Liverpool going behind the atmosphere relaxed and City began to find their rhythm.
 Liverpool, whose title hopes rested on them beating Newcastle and an unlikely favour from West Ham, conceded in the 20th minute as Martin Skrtel diverted into his own net following a cross from the left by Yoan Gouffran.
 Champions-elect City wrapped things up either side of half-time.
 Samir Nasri gave them the breakthrough they had been searching for with a sublime drive from 25 yards that gave West Ham keeper Adrian no chance in the 39th minute, before captain Vincent Kompany prodded home from close range four minutes after the interval to get the party started.
 A mad five minutes handed Liverpool control at Anfield as Daniel Agger steered home Steven Gerrard's long free-kick delivery before Daniel Sturridge scored almost a carbon copy three minutes later - with Shola Ameobi seeing red in between - but it mattered little.
 Paul Dummett saw red three minutes from the end for kicking Luis Suarez to complete a disappointing afternoon for Alan Pardew's side.
 After a lifeless first half Norwich slipped down to the Championship without much fuss as Arsenal cruised to a 2-0 victory at Carrow Road.
 The Gunners, who can be forgiven for having one eye on next week's FA Cup final, wrapped up the win with goals from Aaron Ramsey and Carl Jenkinson.
 Hull, Arsenal's opponents in next week's cup final, signed off their campaign with a 2-0 defeat to Everton at the KC Stadium.
 Steve Bruce's side fell behind early on as James McCarthy scored his first goal since moving to Goodison from Wigan in the summer, before Romelu Lukaku ended his loan spell at the Toffees by notching his 15th of the season.
 Rickie Lambert issued a timely reminder of his England credentials in front of Roy Hodgson with a cool finish in Southampton's 1-1 draw with Manchester United - as Juan Mata grabbed his sixth goal in a United shirt.
 United's failure to win at St Mary's meant Tottenham would finish sixth and secure Europa League football whatever happened at White Hart Lane, but Spurs made light work of Aston Villa anyway.
 They took a 3-0 advantage before half time thanks to Paulinho, an own goal from Nathan Baker and an Emmanuel Adebayor penalty as Villa fell to their 20th defeat and finished 15th.
 Garry Monk's Swansea ended Sunderland's four-match winning streak, which included the scalps of Chelsea and Manchester United, by coming out on top 3-1 at the Stadium of Light.
 Goals from Nathan Dyer and Marvin Emnes effectively ended the game after 14 minutes and though Fabio Borini got one back for the hosts, Wilfried Bony notched his 16th league goal of the season to complete the scoring.
 Cardiff signed off their year in the Premier League, after their relegation was confirmed last week, with a 2-1 defeat to Chelsea.
 Boyhood fan Craig Bellamy's early strike looked to be sending them away with a great result, but Jose Mourinho's Chelsea hit back with goals from Andre Schurrle and Fernando Torres.
 Fulham also bowed out with a 2-2 draw at Crystal Palace.  Dwight Gayle bagged a brace to take his recent tally to four goals in two games, with 19-year-old Cauley Woodrow equalising for the hosts in between, before Chris David ensured it ended all square late on.
 West Brom brought the curtain down on their disappointing season by finishing directly above the trapdoor as Gareth McAuley's own goal and a Charlie Adam strike made it 2-1 to Stoke at the Hawthorns, Stephane Sessegnon having equalised in between times.
results.title: Premier League final day round-up

results.body:
Manchester City were confirmed as Premier League champions on Sunday for the second time in three seasons.
 As had been the case in 2012, City secured the title on the final day of the campaign, albeit without the same level of tension that accompanied their maiden Premier League triumph.
 Two years ago, a last-gasp goal from Sergio Aguero against QPR proved decisive as City edged out rivals Manchester United on goal difference.
 Yet City were not reliant on late drama this time around, as they recorded a routine 2-0 victory over West Ham, ensuring the efforts of second-placed Liverpool proved immaterial.
 Goals from Samir Nasri and captain Vincent Kompany were enough to see off a West Ham side with nothing but pride to play for.
 Liverpool, who began the final round of games two points behind Manuel Pellegrini's men, came from behind to beat Newcastle United 2-1 at Anfield, but it was to no avail.
 City's success comes in their first season under Pellegrini, who succeeded Roberto Mancini in June.
 The champions - who won 27 of their 38 matches - finished the campaign with 102 goals and a goal difference of +65.
results.title: City secure Premier League glory

results.body:
Samir Nasri found the net in the 39th minute and Vincent Kompany added another tally just after halftime as Manchester City beat West Ham United and secured their second English Premier League title in three years.
 In front of their home fans at Etihad Stadium, Manchester City rolled past West Ham United for a 2-0 victory and secured their second English Premier League title in three years.
 Samir Nasri found the net in the 39th minute and captain Vincent Kompany added another tally just after halftime for Manchester City, who needed just one point to be crowned league champions.
 Manchester City finish the season atop the table with 86 points and a staggering +65 goal differential.
 Check back shortly with The National for a full match report and analysis.
 sports@thenational.ae
Follow our sports coverage on twitter at @SprtNationalUAE
results.title: Manchester City secure English Premier League title with win over West Ham United

results.body:
It was a routine home victory for City, with goals from Samir Nasri and captain Vincent Kompany - although point would have been enough for Manuel Pellegrini's side to regain the crown.
 A home defeat to Chelsea and the late collapse at Crystal Palace saw Liverpool's chances of a first title in 24-years slip away and City took full advantage by winning their last five games.
 "Big teams cannot be satisfied with one title," said Pellegrini after the game.  "This club and players deserve more titles." "
A nervous Liverpool meanwhile beat nine-man Newcastle 2-1 to end the season on a high and claim second spot.  They'll be disappointed with their end to the season but can take a lot of heart - in August nobody predicted that they would challenge for the title.
 Liverpool fought back from behind to win thanks to two goals in as many minutes from Daniel Agger and Daniel Sturridge, with Newcastle's Shola Ameobi, who was likely making his final appearance for the club, after seeing red for comments he made to the ref following that second goal.
 Elsewhere, a stunning goal from Aaron Ramsey helped Arsenal to a routine 2-nil win at Norwich, which confirmed the home team's relegation to the Championship, joining Fulham and Cardiff.
 Tottenham claimed sixth spot with a 3-nil win over Aston Villa and Chelsea ended the season with a win - add a striker in the summer and they'll most certainly be contenders for the title next season.
 Last year's champions Manchester United drew with Southampton to finish in a disappointing seventh with 64 points, 22 points behind City, with the search for their new manager continuing following the sacking of the 'chosen one' David Moyes.
results.title: EPL round-up: Man City win Premier League title

results.body:
Manchester City avoided the drama and late heroics that were required in 2012 to win the title, and dispatched West Ham with relative ease to claim the 2014 Premier League title.  Samir Nasri and Vincent Kompany did the damage as Manuel Pellegrini's side finished off a double in his first year in charge of the club.
 City had all of the ball in the opening ten minutes, showing patience just like they did in the mid-week against Aston Villa.  David Silva got their first good chance on goal just past the ten minute mark, volleying a cross from Pablo Zabaleta well over the crossbar.
 Aleksandar Kolarov was denied by Adrián in the 25th minute when the West Ham goalkeeper just managed to palm the ball over the bar, to keep the match scoreless.
 The goal that everyone knew was coming finally arrived in the 39th minute off the boot of Samir Nasri.  The midfielder picked up the ball 25-yards from goal, took a could dribbles forward into a pocket of space between three West Ham players.  None of them even considered closing Nasri down, so he happily fired a scorching low show inside the far post to put City up 1-0.
 David Silva nearly doubled the City lead right before halftime, but his deflected shot from close range hammered off the post.
 Four minutes into the second half, City's captain Vincent Kompany gave his team a 2-0 lead, taking advantage of a fortuitous bounce in front of the West Ham goal.  A cross into the box bounced off a West Ham player, falling right to Kompany who had inside position on Winston Reid, right in front of Adrián.  The defender simply gave the ball a solid kick, and sent the Ethiad Stadium crowd into a joyous, bouncing frenzy.
 City kept searching for a third goal, playing at a pace somewhere between cruise control and just making sure that West Ham didn't get any ideas about coming back.  It was enough to finish off the match and allow the celebrations to begin in earnest for players and fans alike.
 City finished the season with 86 points, two points clear of Liverpool in second place.
 Manchester City: Hart, Zabaleta, Kompany, Demichelis, Kolarov, Garcia, Touré (Negredo 86'), Nasri, Silva (Milner 76'), Agüero, Džeko (Fernadinho 69')
Goals: Nasri (39'), Kompany (49')
West Ham United: Adrián, O'Brien, Reid, Tomkins, McCartney, Noble, Diame (J. Cole 81'), Taylor, Downing, Nolan (Jarvis 64'), Carroll (C. Cole 72')
results.title: Manchester City vs. West Ham United: Final score 2-0, City win the title in efficient, effective fashion

results.body:
Daniel Munthe Agger and Daniel Sturridge scored second-half goals to lead Liverpool to a 2-1 victory over Newcastle United in both teams' English Premier League finale on Sunday night.
 Liverpool could have won the league title with a victory, coupled with a Manchester City loss, but Manchester City beat West Ham United 2-0 to secure their second league title in three years.
 Check back shortly with The National for a full match report.
 sports@thenational.ae
Follow our sports coverage on twitter at @SprtNationalUAE
results.title: Liverpool do what they can but it is not enough to catch Man City

results.body:
Samir Nasri fired a potentially title-winning bullet to give Manchester City a first-half lead against West Ham.
 With City just needing a point against the Hammers to secure their second Premier League trophy in three years, it was all even until the Frenchman rasped home from 25 yards in the 39th minute.
 That goal, coupled with Liverpool losing 1-0 at home to Newcastle, left City looking pretty on top of the table, but after leading by the exact same score, with a goal in the exact same minute at this point two season's ago at home to QPR, fans will know how quickly a game can change...
results.title: Freaky! Samir Nasri bullet goal gives Manchester City exact replica of dramatic 2012 situation against QPR

results.body:
Samir Nasri's 39th-minute goal is probably going to send Manchester City to its second Premier League title in the last three years.  City only needs to draw West Ham in order to fend off Liverpool, which trails Newcastle United 1-0 at halftime.
 City have only spent 14 days atop the table all season, but it looks like Manuel Pellegrini is going to have his team in the right place when it counts.
 UPDATE: City took a 2-0 lead on Vincent Kompany's goal.  Game over.  Title over.
 RELATED: Manchester United Fans Hired a Plane to Troll Steven Gerrard
results.title: Samir Nasri's Goal Probably Wrapped Up the Premier League Title for Manchester City [UPDATE]

results.body:
The champagne is popped and the cigars are lit but how did each man perform as Pellegrini's Blues secured the title?
 For the second time in three seasons, Manchester City are Premier League champions after a routine 2-0 home win over West Ham.
 Samir Nasri got the opening goal and captain Vincent Kompany warned up for trophy-hoisting duties by adding the second, but who ruled and who had a Rupert?
 Here, the Mirror's David Anderson gives his analysis of each team's performance, man by man...
 Martin Demichelis: 8 Looks like the player Pellegrini always thought he was.  Booked.
 Aleksandar Kolarov: 7 Was denied a superb goal when Adrian touched over his piledriver.
 Samir Nasri: 8 Precise finish for his goal and made the second.  Man of the match.
results.title: Manchester City 2-0 West Ham: Player ratings from the Mirror's David Anderson

results.body:
Manchester City went into half time with the advantage in the race for the Premier League title.
 Manchester City went into half time with the advantage in the race for the Premier League title.
 Samir Nasri's strike put the Blues 1-0 up against West Ham, while Liverpool trail Newcastle by the same score at home after Martin Skrtel own goal.
 The Blues played powerfully from the off and dominated the Hammers, but nerves were starting to creep in before the Frenchman's strike from distance beat Adrian despite the keeper getting a touch to it.
 The Blues are now just 45 minutes plus stoppage time away from a second title in three seasons, but it remains to be seen if there is a late twist.
results.title: Half time report on City v West Ham

results.body:
With a solitary point enough to end all the arguments, against West Ham at The Etihad Stadium, Vincent Kompany will surely hold aloft the Barclays Premier League trophy at the close of business for another season this Sunday afternoon.
 If there is a helicopter on hand, in case anything unforeseen lets Liverpool back in it, it will presumably be in one of the car parks that surround The Etihad, rather than hovering somewhere between the two venues, as happens when the outcome is in the balance.
 The trophy is surely heading back to City, after a two-year absence, but are they worthy champions?  Here's 10 reasons why they are.
 Yaya Toure - is there a more fearsome sight for opposing teams than the foraging Toure in full flight?  That's what you call a rhetorical question.
 No need to conduct a poll.  We all know the answer.  When City play their favoured 4-2-3-1 formation, he's one of the midfield anchor men, usually alongside Fernandinho, which tells you something about his defensive qualities.
 But there's far more to his game than that, as illustrated by a run that covered almost the length of the field for City's final goal against Aston Villa and took his Barclays Premier League tally for the season to 20, making him joint-second alongside Daniel Sturridge on the list of scorers.
 David Silva and Samir Nasri - what a double act.  With Toure and Fernandinho behind them, these two have licence to let their dancing feet dazzle the opposition, and they are seldom out of step.
 The finishing of Edin Dzeko, Sergio Aguero and Toure may have helped keep City's goals-for column ticking over, but so too has the ingenuity of Silva and Nasri.
 When packed defences pitch up at The Etihad, who better than City's two attacking midfielders, both master craftsmen with the ball at their feet, to unpick them?  Another rhetorical question.  There's no-one better anywhere in the Premier League.
 Manuel Pellegrini - dull as ditchwater for us quotes-hungry sports writers, perhaps, but a canny operator who has commanded the respect of his players and who should, perhaps, be congratulated for steering well clear of the inevitable end-of-season managerial mind games.
 They were once viewed as spicy, hugely-entertaining verbal jousts, but not anymore.  We can't win the League, no we can't, no we're just a little horse, and so on and so on, ad nauseam.
 Pellegrini's deadpan delivery that 'everyone is still in with a chance' during the run-in may not have made riveting reading, but it was preferable to the nonsense spouted elsewhere.
 Defence - it has been clear for a few weeks that Liverpool, rather than Chelsea, were City's only genuine rivals, but can any team have an authentic claim to being England's finest when they have such a porous defence.
 When our very own, and, more to the point, Liverpool's very own, Jamie Carragher describes their defending as 'unacceptable', you know something is amiss.
 They were all over the place at Crystal Palace, not least when Dwight Gayle was allowed time and space inside the area to fire home the most dramatic of equalisers.
 City have conceded a goal a game so far, but that made it 49 in 37 for Liverpool.  Unacceptable, as Carragher rightly said.
 Sergio Aguero - Luis Suarez is out on his own as the Premier League's leading marksmen with 31 goals, but would he have been if Aguero had been injury-free instead of seemingly jinxed this season?
 It must be a concern for Argentina, ahead of the World Cup, the way he keeps wincing in pain after pressing the accelerator and feeling a twinge in his hamstring or groin, and it can't be doing much for Pellegrini's peace of mind, either.
 For all his fitness problems, though, the little frontrunner has still clocked up 17 goals to be joint-third top scorer in the League.
 They tend to be important ones, too, as demonstrated against QPR two years ago, when he settled matters with virtually the last kick of the season and 'Aguero-o-o-o-o ' became a best-selling t-shirt slogan.
 Squad - injuries happen, see above, and when they claim one of your key players, you need adequate cover, if you are serious about challenging for top honours.
 The same applies to form, and City have been able to absorb Alvaro Negredo losing his way mid-season, thanks to Edin Dzeko proving such an effective replacement.
 The Beast, as Negredo is affectionately known among Etihad patrons, looked unstoppable for the first half of the campaign, intimidating opposing defenders with his physical presence, holding the ball up and, more often than not, despatching it in the net.
 When those qualities began to desert him, Dzeko stepped in seamlessly and began doing the same, equally as well.  Crucial goals with head and feet have re-established him as City's main spearhead.
 Vincent Kompany - there's a case for saying he hasn't been striding the stage quite as imperiously as before, but that just shows how good he was last season.
 Still one of the best central defenders in the country and still a captain who leads by example.  He has become the face of the City dressing room, and it is an entirely acceptable one, the way he conducts himself on the pitch, and speaks eloquently, passionately and always reasonably off it.
 What a signing, from Bundesliga side Hamburg six years ago.  The best £6million anyone has ever spent.
 FFP - no, not Financial Fair Play but Fields, Facilities and Planning.
 City may be in hot water with UEFA for apparently flouting the recently introduced rules governing income and expenditure, but fair play to them for the way they are ploughing money into transforming one of the most deprived areas of Manchester by creating lush new training pitches, constructing state-of-the-art facilities and meeting every last requirement - including educational needs - for future generations of players.
 By the time it is all finished, it will have transformed the face of East Manchester, and they deserve praise and gratitude for that, rather than sanctions.
 Pablo Zabaleta - if ever there was an unsung hero, it has to be this unassuming, approachable Argentina right-back.
 When the money started rolling in from Sheikh Mansour, and world-renowned names began being lined up for every area of the team, his days looked numbered.
 Yet he has survived the overhaul of City's squad in style and made the number two position his own.  Transfer speculation is a way of life at The Etihad these days, but how often do you see City being linked with a right-back?
 The only movement in that area has been speculation that Micah Richards, once touted as England's right-back for the foreseeable future, may be on his way this summer.
 If he does leave, it will be down solely to Zabaleta's remarkable consistency as a full-back who can defend and also attack down the right.
 James Milner - not as flamboyant or spectacular as Silva or Nasri, but the statistics will tell you he contributes almost as much.
 There is a website that deals in facts and figures and lists each player's strengths and weaknesses.  Under strengths, Milner gets a tick for each category.
 Under weaknesses, the word 'none' appears.  Praise indeed, but it will come as no surprise to his manager, or his team-mates, for that matter.
 His assists, whether from an unselfish pass or cutback from the bye-line, have gone a long way towards City's goals-for column reaching three figures.
 When you have flair players like Silva and Nasri, it is important to balance it with a grafter like Milner, who takes on the workload willingly but also provides width and an attacking threat of his own with his forays down the right flank.
results.title: Manchester City will be worthy winners in title race: Sportsmail looks at 10 reasons why champions-elect deserve victory

results.body:
This time, they spared the emotions of their supporters.  There was no late drama.  No bedlam.  For once, Manchester City resisted any temptation to make life unnecessarily hard for themselves.  Instead, they just rolled up their sleeves and set about finishing off their work.  They are the champions of England and they did it in a way that made the old City, the club where once they said it should have a Government health warning, feel like a fading memory.
 By the time it was all done, Manuel Pellegrini's team had clocked up 102 goals and it was probably just a surprise they did not manage to get one more to equal Chelsea's 2010 record from the Premier League era.  Sergio Agüero is probably thinking the same after the sitter he passed up from one of Pablo Zabaleta's overlapping runs.
 No matter.  The final goal of the afternoon, courtesy of Vincent Kompany, could not generate the moshpit that Agüero set in motion on the final day two seasons ago but, for once, City's crowd will probably appreciate a party with a chill-out zone.
 They were ahead, six minutes before the interval, when Samir Nasri picked out the bottom corner from 25 yards but the crowd's nerves had already been soothed by that stage because of the news of Martin Skrtel's own goal at Anfield.
 The positions had not changed when Kompany made it 2-0 four minutes into the second half and, ultimately, Liverpool's second-half recovery was immaterial.  By that stage, nobody at the Etihad was concerning themselves too much with what was going on the other end of the M62.
 'Nobody remembers who comes second,' read one of the banners.  And City - calm, professional, slick, and showing a level of know-how that was once beyond them - made absolutely certain this wild, oscillating title race had had its final twist.
 West Ham were generous opponents in what could conceivably be Sam Allardyce's last game in charge.  They defended stoutly for the opening half an hour but it has never been the structure and organisation of Allardyce's team that dismays their supporters.  It is the absence of real creativity and, if this is the farewell, the lingering image will be of the chance that came to Andy Carroll from Stewart Downing's cross in the second half.  The first touch sent it out for a corner and Carroll was substituted a few minutes later.
 At that stage, the victory songs had already started and the Etihad was in the process of its third Poznan of the afternoon.  For Yaya Touré, the celebrations were tarnished by a hamstring injury that forced him off before the end and, briefly, Agüero's barge on Mark Noble led to a confrontation between the two sets of players that was completely out of keeping with the rest of the afternoon.  Yet by the end the biggest problem for City was getting their supporters off the pitch so they could start the presentation.  "We want to see the trophy," the public announcer reminded everyone.
 Nasri had set it up with the accuracy of his finish before the interval, taking advantage of the way Kevin Nolan and Matt Taylor did not close him down to rifle in a diagonal shot from 25 yards.  Adrián, the West Ham goalkeeper, got a glove to the ball but it went in off the post and a happy air of inevitability descended.
 Kompany's goal came after a lucky ricochet off Nolan from a corner, leaving him with the ball inside the six-yard area, and what a moment it was for City's captain bearing in mind it was his mistake at Anfield last month that had threatened to extinguish his team's chances of glory.
results.title: Manchester City 2-0 West Ham United | Premier League match report

results.body:
Sergio Aguero returns from a groin injury to start against West Ham for Manchester City, who need just a point to be crowned Premier League champions at the Etihad Stadium.
 Aguero was left out for the 4-0 win over Aston Villa after suffering the injury against Everton, but partners Edin Dzeko - who scored twice in midweek - up front.
 Fernandinho also surprisingly makes way in central midfield with Javi Garcia starting alongside Yaya Toure.
 Manchester City: Hart, Zabaleta, Kompany, Demichelis, Kolarov, Garcia, Toure, Nasri, Silva, Aguero, Dzeko
Substitutes: Pantilimon, Lescott, Clichy, Milner, Fernandinho, Negredo, Jovetic
West Ham: Adrian, O'Brien, Tomkins, Reid, McCartney, Noble, Taylor, Downing, Nolan, Diame, Carroll
Substitutes: Jarvis, Armero, Vaz Te, Collins, Jaaskelainen, C Cole, J Cole
Meanwhile, Jordan Henderson returns from suspension to start for Liverpool, who need to beat Newcastle at Anfield and hope West Ham defeat City if they are to win the title.
 Daniel Agger also starts in defence for LIverpool.
 Liverpool: Mignolet, Johnson, Skrtel, Agger, Flanagan, Henderson, Gerrard, Allen, Sterling, Suarez, Sturridge
Substitutes: Jones, Toure, Sakho, Cissokho, Lucas, Coutinho, Aspas
Newcastle: Krul, S Taylor, Williamson, Coloccini, Haidara, Debuchy, Anita, Tiote, Gouffran, Sissoko, Shola Ameobi
Substitutes: Elliot, Santon, Yanga-Mbiwa, Satka, Dummett, Sammy Ameobi, De Jong
Southampton v Manchester United
Ryan Giggs has left himself out of Manchester United's match-day squad at Southampton, ensuring his record of scoring in every Premier League season comes to an end.
 Meanwhile, Robin van Persie starts up front with Juan Mata behind him, while there is no place in the squad for James Wilson, who scored twice on his debut for the club against Hull on Tuesday.
 Luke Shaw starts for Southampton, with reports United are set to make a £27 million bid for him, as does Adam Lallana, who is set to seal a £20m move to Liverpool next week.

results.title: Aguero returns to start for City

results.body:
El Manchester City necesita un punto en su estadio ante el West Ham para ganar el domingo la Premier League inglesa y dar al técnico chileno Manuel Pellegrini su primera liga en Europa.
 El director técnico del Liverpool Brendan Rodgers da órdenes desde la línea de juego en el partido contra el Crystal Palace.
 El chileno de 60 años, se convertiría además en el primer entrenador no europeo en ganar la Premier League.
 Sólo el Liverpool del atacante uruguayo Luis Suárez, el mejor jugador de la temporada, podría arrebatarle el título.  Se encuentra a dos puntos y tiene que ganar al Newcastle y esperar que el City pierda.
 Los rivales del City y el Liverpool no se juegan nada, pero el West Ham tiene a dos antiguos jugadores del Liverpool, Andy Carroll y Stewart Downing, que seguramente querrán hacerle un favor a sus excompañeros.
 Sería el cuarto título de Liga del Manchester City y el segundo en tres años.
 El Liverpool, que ha ganado 18, cerraría con el título la sequía más larga de su historia: 24 años sin una liga.
 Todo está casi sellado en el descenso.  El Fulham londinense y el Cardiff City galés ya son equipos de segunda división.
 La tercera plaza del descenso está prácticamente asignada al Norwich City, que está tres puntos por detrás del West Bromwich Albion, pero con una desventaja de 17 goles en la media goleadora, la primera variable con la que se resuelven los empates a puntos.
 La victoria ante el Aston Villa 4-0 el miércoles en el estadio Etihad hizo que el City se pusiera por primera vez al frente de la tabla desde enero y dejó al tercero, el Chelsea de José Mourinho, sin ninguna posibilidad de pelear por la corona.
 "Ahora ya podemos hablar del título, porque si ganamos el próximo partido ganaremos el título", dijo Pellegrini, que podría culminar con un triunfo de prestigio su primera temporada en Inglaterra.
 La buena marcha del City, que ya ganó la Copa de la Liga, y el fracaso del Chelsea, que cerrará la temporada en blanco, ha recuperado el gran debate sobre los estilos; ¿juego bonito o juego efectivo?, ¿posesión del balón o contraataque?.
 Pellegrini se refirió a él.  Ganar la Liga "será muy importante, no sólo por el título, sino por la manera en que vamos a ganarlo, si lo ganamos", explicó.
 "Tenemos un estilo de juego, somos un equipo atractivo, marcamos muchos goles y siempre estamos pensando en marcar más", aseguró el chileno, que ha entrenado a Villarreal, Real Madrid, Málaga y el City desde que llegó a Europa en 2004.
 El City ha marcado 100 goles hasta ahora, uno más que el Liverpool (99) y 31 más que el Chelsea.
 Luis Suárez, en busca del récord goleador
Luis Suárez es el máximo goleador de la Premier con 31 goles y con un solo tanto superaría el récord histórico de Cristiano Ronaldo y Alan Shearer en una liga de 38 partidos como la actual.  Si marcara tres, igualaría el de Shearer y Andy Cole en una liga con 42 partidos.

results.title: Se define la Premier League entre el Manchester City y el Liverpool

results.body:
MANCHESTER -- Sergio Agüero, cuyo agónico gol en tiempo de descuento le dio al Manchester City el título de la Liga Premier hace dos años, se repuso de su lesión y será de la partida el domingo cuando el City enfrente al West Ham en busca de un empate que le daría su segundo campeonato inglés en tres años.
 El técnico Manuel Pellegrini dijo el viernes que "todo el equipo está bien" y disponible para el encuentro.  Agüero es el máximo goleador del club esta temporada, con 28 tantos, pero sufrió una lesión en la ingle en la victoria del sábado por 3-2 sobre Everton y se ausentó del duelo del miércoles con Aston Villa, que el City ganó 4-0.
 El argentino se metió en el corazón de la hinchada del City cuando marcó un gol a los 94 minutos que le dio al club su primer campeonato de liga en más de cuatro décadas en el 2012.
 El cierre de la temporada pondrá de manifiesto la distancia que separa hoy a los dos equipos de Manchester.  Mientras que el City tiene el título casi en el bolsillo, Manchester United está lejos de la punta, a 20 unidades de su vecino, y necesitaría ganarle al Southampton y que Tottenham pierda con Aston Villa para clasificarse raspando a la Europa League.
 La última fecha decidirá asimismo quien acompaña a Fulham y Cardiff a la segunda división.  Norwich está casi condenado, ya que figura antepenúltimo, con tres puntos menos que West Bromwich y una diferencia de goles muy inferior.
 EL CITY A UN PASO DEL TITULO
Dos años atrás el City ganó un campeonato de infarto, por diferencia de goles, luego de anotar dos tantos en tiempo de descuento para ganarle al Queens Park Rangers en casa.
 Le bastará un empate ante West Ham, que está en la mitad de la tabla, ya que le lleva dos unidades al segundo, Liverpool, y tiene un saldo de goles muy superior, 13 tantos.
 El City ganó los tres partidos que jugó con West Ham esta temporada, incluido uno por 6-0 como local en el estadio Etihad.
 CRUZANDO LOS DEDOS
Para que el trofeo regrese a Anfield por primera vez en 24 años, Liverpool debería ganar por goleada a Newcastle y esperar un gran favor de West Ham.
 Solo si Man City pierde con West Ham, Liverpool tendría posibilidades de coronarse, dada la gran diferencia de goles entre ambos.
 Es poco probable que se dé esa combinación, pero en el fútbol nunca se sabe.
 En 1989 a Liverpool le bastaba perder por 1-0 ante Arsenal para salir campeón, pero cayó 2-0 tras ceder un gol a Michael Thomas en tiempo de descuento y Arsenal se llevó el título.
 EL PEOR AÑO DE UNITED
La Europa League está resultando un encarte para los clubes de la Liga Premier, por lo que no clasificarse a esa competencia podría ser una bendición para Manchester United, que se apresta a redondear su peor campaña en mucho tiempo.
 United está séptimo, a tres unidades de Tottenham, y se clasificará si le gana a Southampton y Tottenham pierde con Aston Villa.
 El club es dirigido en forma interina por el jugador Ryan Giggs tras el reciente despido de David Moyes, quien reemplazó este año al legendario Alex Ferguson y no logró buenos resultados.
 Giggs dice que hará lo posible por clasificar al equipo a la Liga Europa.
 "Es importante tener fútbol europeo en Old Trafford", sostuvo.
 Se clasifique o no, esta fue la peor campaña de United en su historia.
 NORWICH CONDENADO
La presencia de Norwich en la Liga Premier está a punto de acabar luego de tres años.
 Los canarios están antepenúltimos, a tres puntos de West Brom y con una desventaja de 17 goles respecto al otro club que peligra.  Ni siquiera una victoria en el cierre de la campaña lo salvará, a menos que ocurra un milagro.
 ¿LA DESPEDIDA DE GIGGS?
 El del domingo podría ser el último partido de Giggs, suponiendo que decida alinearse a sí mismo.
 Con sus 40 años a cuestas y abundantes canas, Giggs todavía no ha dicho si seguirá jugando la próxima temporada, pero es previsible que no lo haga.
 "Esperaré a que termine la campaña y luego lo pensaré un par de semanas", dijo Giggs el martes.
results.title: Se define la Premier League: ¿Man.City o Liverpool?

results.body:
Sería un milagro que el Liverpool fuera esta tarde campeón de la Premier.  Milagro porque el título -sería el primero desde 1990 y cuando se cumple el 25 aniversario del desastre de Hillsborough-ya no depende sólo del Liverpool; también depende de que el West Ham logre batir al Manchester City en el Etihad.  A los hombres de Manuel Pellegrini les basta un punto para hacerse con su cuarta Premier (segunda en tres temporadas) y nadie en su sano juicio apostaría a que no van a saltar al terreno de juego a sentenciar la temporada con una victoria "con estilo", como les ha pedido su entrenador.  El 6-0 que el City le infligió al West Ham en la ida de semifinales de la Copa de la Liga (más otro triunfo por 0-3 en la vuelta), fue recordado ayer por el propio Pellegrini.  "Les ganamos en enero en un buen partido y espero que lo podamos repetir ahora", afirmó el técnico de los 'citizens'.
 El Liverpool, que recibe al Newcastle, lleva haciéndose a la idea de quedarse a las puertas de la Premier desde la derrota ante el Chelsea (0-2) tras 11 partidos sin caer derrotado y el posterior empate (3-3) ante el Crystal Palace, "el peor momento de la temporada", como lo calificó Brendan Rodgers, entrenador de los 'reds'.  Pero quiere valorar el curso en positivo.  "Es un comienzo para el Liverpool, su mejor campaña en la lucha por el título desde 1990", dijo Rodgers.
 El City sólo ha estado en la cabeza de la Premier en total 14 días y sin embargo llega a la jornada final del campeonato con todas las garantías de lograr el segundo título de campeón inglés en tres temporadas.  El City espera tomar el relevo de su vecino, el United, que en el último encuentro de Ryan Giggs en su banquillo como interino visita al Southampton.
 El Chelsea de José Mourinho, el otro equipo que ha luchado casi hasta el final por esta Premier, visita al Cardiff sin opciones.
results.title: La fiesta del Manchester City, a punto

results.body:
Listo.  Con un empate ante el West Ham conseguirá su cuarta Premier League.
 El Manchester City tiene todo a su favor para gritar hoy campeón.  Desde las 9 de la mañana (hora peruana) recibirá al West Ham en el Etihad Stadium esperando no tener que sufrir tanto como en el 2012, donde recién celebraron con un gol agónico del 'Kun' Agüero.
 Manuel Pellegrini, el técnico chileno, espera celebrar su primer título en Europa, que sería la cuarta Premier League en la historia de los 'citizens'.  Hasta con un empate, por la diferencia de goles, quedarán encima del Liverpool, que espera solo un milagro.
 Los 'Reds' deben superar en casa al Newcastle y luego esperar que el City tropiece.  Mientras que el Manchester United pelea su última chance de llegar a la Euroliga.  Debe ganarle al Southampton y esperar que el Tottenham caiga.
results.title: El City está a solo un punto de ser campeón

results.body:
El Manchester City se prepara para vivir mañana otra jornada histórica, aunque espera que la consecución de la Premier no sea tan dramática como en 2012.  Entonces también lo tenía todo a favor, dependía de sí mismo y jugaba en el Etihad, pero no logró el título hasta el descuento con dos goles de Edin Dzeko y Kun Agüero que remontaron el 1-2 del Queens Park Rangers.  Los 'citzens' ganaron por 3-2 y se proclamaron campeones de Inglaterra por tercera vez, primera tras 44 años de espera, por mejor 'average' general que su eterno rival, el United.
 Pablo Zabaleta, autor del 1-0 en ese partido, tiene muy presente el precedente.  "El miércoles dimos un paso de gigante (4-0 al Aston Villa) pero aún tenemos un partido y hace dos años vimos cómo esto puede cambiar rápido".  Agüero, baja el miércoles con molestias musculares, está recuperado.
 "Sabemos que un empate es suficiente, pero jugaremos para ganar", dice, rotundo, Zabaleta, que recela del West Ham pese a que el City le ha ganado tres veces esta temporada: 1-3 en Premier y 6-0 y 0-3 en semis de la Copa de la Liga conquistada en febrero.  "Están salvados del descenso pero tienen muy buenos jugadores y marcan en jugadas ensayadas.  Será duro".
 Uno de ellos es Andy Carroll, que jugó en el Liverpool una temporada (2011-12) antes de cederlo primero (2012-13) y traspasarlo el verano pasado al West Ham.  Sólo ha marcado dos goles desde que reapareció tras una larga lesión, pero los 'reds' confían en él para lograr el milagro; ganar al Newcastle y dar el vuelco a la tabla.
 "El West Ham tiene talento y si es capaz de ganar 2-0 al Tottenham (el pasado sábado), puede hacerlo ante el City", confía Brendan Rodgers, cuyo discurso ha cambiado en apenas unas horas.  El martes, tras ver cómo el Crystal Palace le remontaba un 0-3 en los últimos diez minutos para acabar empatando, aseguró que la Premier ya estaba decidida.  "Lucharemos hasta el final", rectificó al día siguiente y ayer también: "Esto no ha acabado".  Además, confirmó que está a punto de renovar.
 Otro aliado del Liverpool es San Allardyce.  "A cualquiera le gustaría ver al Liverpool ganar el título y a mí que lo haga Steven Gerrard", confesó el técnico del West Ham.  "Ha estado en el club toda su vida y es lo último que le queda por ganar.  El City sólo ha perdido en casa ante el Chelsea, pero intentaremos aguar la fiesta".
results.title: El Manchester City espera no sufrir como en 2012

results.body:
También desde las 11, en la última jornada de la Premier League, los "Reds" se verán las caras con las "Urracas", con la obligación de ganar y aguardar una derrota del Manchester City para celebrar un título 24 años después de la vez anterior.  Televisará ESPN.  En simultáneo, otros ocho encuentros, destacándose Cardiff-Chelsea y Southampton-Manchester United
En el marco de la Fecha 38 de la Premier League, la principal atención se centrará en el Etihad Stadium, donde Manchester City recibirá al West Ham con la oportunidad de salir campeón por sus propios medios.  De todas maneras, las esperanzas también se alojarán en Anfield, donde Liverpool medirá sus fuerzas ante Newcastle desde las 11 con la intención de buscar el milagro de la consagración.  A dos unidades de los "Ciudadanos" y una desventaja de 13 en la diferencia de goles, los dirigidos por Brendan Rodgers deberán conseguir las tres unidades y aguardar una derrota de los de Manuel Pellegrini.
results.title: Liverpool recibirá al Newcastle y esperará el milagro para volver a festejar un campeonato

results.body: Manchester City, con los argentinos Sergio Agüero, Pablo Zabaleta y Martín Demichelis, buscará hoy consagrarse como campeón de la Premier League, cuando reciba a West Ham desde las 11.  Al conjunto de Manuel Pellegrini le alcanza con un empate para festejar el título, ya que le lleva dos puntos de ventaja al escolta Liverpool, además de 13 tantos de diferencia para el caso de igualdad de puntos.  Por su parte, el conjunto rojo jugará en Anfield Road ante Newcastle, con la necesidad de ganar y que el City pierda para quedarse con el certamen.
results.title: Camino a la gloria

results.body:
Su paso por la Premier ha sido una carrera de obstáculos.  Dejó un Betis en caída libre y llegó a un West Brom en convulsión, sumido en la lucha por la permanencia y en problemas extradeportivos como el caso Anelka.  Pepe Mel (Madrid, 28 Febrero 1963) da por buena la lección aprendida tras lograr la salvación y afronta la última jornada con su futuro incierto.  "En Inglaterra no conocen el entrenador que soy", se lamenta.  Gracias a su carácter afable, el técnico español se ha ganado el cariño de la ciudad deportiva del West Brom a pesar de la barrera del idioma.  "Me iré de vacaciones a Benidorm para mejorar el inglés", bromea en un corrillo de periodistas locales.
 ¿La Premier es tan fiera como la pintan?  Hombre, si la ves desde el punto de vista del West Brom, del Norwich, del Sunderland, del Cardiff y del Fulham, sí.  Cada partido es una aventura.  Es complicado por el nivel de los rivales, pero se pueden hacer cosas.  Es una liga excitante para trabajar.  En su caso el camino ha estado plagado de obstáculos pero salvará al equipo por diferencia de goles.  Lo importante es el objetivo final.  Cuando a uno le marcan un objetivo y lo consigue, por lo menos tiene la tranquilidad de conciencia de saber que ha cumplido.  Ha sido difícil por mil problemas, no voy a empezar a enumerarlos.  Cada semana teníamos una prueba diferente que superar y lo hemos hecho.  ¿Es cierto que sus jugadores le pidieron que renunciara al fútbol de posesión para lograr la permanencia?  Llegamos a un acuerdo entre jugadores y cuerpo técnico... no fue exactamente así.  Está claro que no puedes hacer algo que va contra la naturaleza de los futbolistas.  Estábamos en un momento crítico, necesotábamos ganar partidos, sumar puntos y es mejor que el jugador esté cómodo en el campo.  Pero a usted le ficharon por su estilo...  Ya... pero en ese momento lo más importante para el club era mantener la categoría.  Ahora es cuando hay que decidir si de verdad el West Brom quiere cambiar.  ¿Con Pepe Mel?  Como decía, ahora tienen que pensar si quieren cambiar o seguir con su tradición.  Las dos cosas me parecerán bien.  Yo he estado muy a gusto aquí y me voy con el cariño de la gente.  Conseguimos la permanencia, el objetivo por el que me contrataron.  ¿Le apetece seguir en la Premier?  Hay un último partido apasionante contra el Stoke City y lo quiero vivir porque no sé si será el último.  Después del pitido final, comenzaremos a hablar de futuro.  Mi deseo es poder ser yo mismo en el West Brom y tener la oportunidad de que el West Brom se parezca más a mí.  Para eso me ficharon.  ¿Cuál ha sido su mayor satisfacción en la Premier?  Cuando yo llegué, a falta de 17 partidos, teníamos partidos en los que nadie contaba con puntuar: Everton, Liverpool, Chelsea, Tottenham, Manchester City, Manchester United.. .  Sin embargo, en la gran mayoría sacamos puntos.  Eso fue una satisfacción.  ¿El idioma ha sido un obstáculo?  Hombre, es obvio que sí.  Un entrenador tiene que transmitir y a mí me gustaría poder hablar con los jugadores como lo estoy haciendo con usted ahora.  Me ha costado al principio y, sin duda alguna, ha sido una barrera.  ¿Esta Premier la ganará el City o la perderá el Liverpool?  En el fútbol va todo unido.  Hay ganadores y perdedores porque es un juego y la suerte está en liza.  Simplemente el Liverpool ha fallado más que el City.  Hay que verlo de esta forma.  Por supuesto tener grandísimos jugadores ayuda, pero ha sido una liga apasionante.  Sin duda alguna, el City sería el justo ganador.  Lo que envidio del City es la posibilidad de jugar con Agüero, Yaya Touré, Silva, etc...  ¿Pellegrini merecía un gran título europeo?  Manuel merece el título pero igual lo merecería Brendan Rogers.  Los dos han estado a una gran altura.  Pellegrini es un poco un privilegiado.  Yo admiro sobre todo su trabajo con el Málaga y con el Villarreal, donde demostró que está destinado a hacer cosas.  Es más sencillo cuando estás en el Real Madrid o en el ManCity.  Me quedo con el Manuel Pellegrini del Villarreal y el Málaga.  Por el fútbol que defiende, ¿Pepe Mel prefiere que gane la Premier un equipo que trate bien el balón antes que un equipo que renuncie a él?  Yo creo que Arsenal, Liverpool, Manchester City, Swansea, Southampton.. .  son equipos que se acercan a lo que yo pienso que es el fútbol.  Y todos esos equipos han hecho muy buenas ligas, uno de ellos será campeón.  Por lo tanto, sí, la Premier, como otras ligas europeas, premia el buen hacer con el balón.  En España se envidia el carácter competitivo de la Premier, pero este año no hay mucho que envidiar.  ¿Ganará el Atleti el campeonato?  Yo soy madrileño y me gustaría que la ganara.  Sería bueno para el fútbol español, daría un aire fresco que no fueran siempre los dos grandes.  Están teniendo una temporada apasionante y han merecido estar ahí.  Si al final gana el Barça, también será porque se lo ha merecido.  ¿Le ha entristecido ver cómo se ha hundido su Betis y la situación institucional en la que se encuentra?  Es un tema muy doloroso para mí.  Soy del Betis y mi familia es bética.  Hay que pensar en el futuro y la única forma de salir de los problemas es uniéndose, como ocurrió en 2010 cuando yo llegué.  Se ascendió y se acabó en Europa.  Es mi deseo.  Un equipo como el Betis, no sufriría tanto financieramente en la Premier...  Es una desgracia decirlo.  Pero en el mundo del fútbol, como buen business que es, el dinero lo es todo.  Si el Betis tuviera dinero, con la cantidad de afición y el apoyo social que tiene, sería un gran club a nivel mundial.  Para desgracia del Betis, España no es como Inglaterra: si un equipo desciende recibe el mismo dinero a través de televisión y otros conductos.  Pasas de ganar más de 30 millones por TV [el colista QPR recibió 39 millones de libras la temporada pasada] a recibir dos y medio.
results.title: 'El City sería un justo ganador'

results.body:
LONDRES -- Los fanáticos del Manchester City van a estar haciendo una de dos cosas esta semana, después de haber visto cómo un juego que fue desgastando la paciencia ante el Aston Villa el lunes se convirtió en un diluvio en el segundo tiempo, literal y meteorológicamente hablando.
 Lo primero que se debe hacer como un fanático del City, por supuesto, es empezar a preocuparse.  Ningún canto triunfalista, ninguna bandera agitándose, ni bombos y platillos, sólo el eterno temor.  Morderse las uñas, temblar, mover las rodillas sin parar, vagar sin rumbo -- mucho temor y nerviosismo.  La segunda cosa es seguir haciendo lo primero hasta llegar a un estado tal que incluso caminar se vuelva difícil.
 La noticia de que Sergio Agüero ha pasado la prueba física y tomará su lugar de titular ante el West Ham envía la memoria colectiva dos años atrás, hacia una tarde de 2012 llena de tensión contra los Queens Park Rangers.  Un recién llegado al planeta podría haber pensado que el excepcional gol ganador del título había sido anotado por un jugador llamado, improbablemente, "Agüerooooooooooooo", y que las personas presentes nunca habían sido testigo de un gol en todas sus largas vidas, pero en verdad, el Manchester City ha hecho sufrir tanto a sus fanáticos en medio de muchos melodramas durante los últimos días-de-la-temporada que deberían estar acostumbrados a eso, para bien o para mal.
 Esto, por supuesto, es algo más fácil de decir que de hacer.  Para probar este punto, echaremos un rápido vistazo a este pequeño resumen:
St.  James 'Park, 1968 -- Una victoria por 4-3.  Franny Lee en la multitud rodeado de muchachos con parkas de lana.  Campeones de toda Inglaterra.
 Maine Road, 1983 -- Luton Town, las zapatillas sin cordones de David Pleat, Brian Horton, Paul Walsh, 1-0 ante Raddy Antic con tres minutos para el final.  El inquietante comentario en televisión de John Motson: "Uno de los grandes del fútbol Inglés... va al descenso".
 Charlton Athletic, 1985 -- Cantando canciones muy tontas de pie sobre una mesa húmeda en Yates Wine Lodge, desorientado, gran conmoción y pavor.  Perdí mi suéter, mis zapatos y mis compañeros en la aglomeración.
 Upton Park, 1987 -- Abajo de nuevo a la segunda división después de un inesperado y rápido encuentro con los fanáticos del West Ham.
 Bradford, 1989 -- Exprimidos detrás de la tela metálica en Valley Parade tratando de evitar que mi banana inflable estalle en esos brillantes picos de color rojizo y ámbar.  Clever Trevor Morley con segundos en el reloj, mirando a un lado y luego al otro para averiguar discretamente si su gol había valido no.
 Sunderland, 1992 -- Un breve respiro, ya que ellos estaban en crisis, no el City.  Wearsiders, los 13,000, en la tribuna del Platt Lane.  Los grandes pantalones disco de Niall Quinn ondeando a media asta.
 Liverpool, 1996 -- La emocionante remontada después de ir dos goles abajo ante un equipo que ni siquiera estaba interesado; Steve Lomas por el lateral aguantando para un empate 2-2 que no era bueno para nadie.  Alan Ball con su jogging y gorra dirigiendo el desastre como un regordete Sam Peckinpah en su terrible suntuosidad.  El tremendo olor agrio de las esperanzas destrozadas.  El descenso, otra vez.
 Stoke, 1998 -- El caos absoluto de un descenso a la tercera división del fútbol inglés.  Port Vale, Huddersfield y Portsmouth (de Alan Ball) ganaron de visitantes para descender al City.  Las cicatrices mentales que pueden quedar tras una tarde como esa.  El City en la tercera división.
 El más grande de todos, Wembley contra Gillingham en 1999 - Paul Dickov deslizándose a través de la lluvia en el quinto minuto del tiempo añadido; la mitad de los fans que se iban volvieron; arriba, abajo y todo alrededor.  Nicky Weaver corriendo el largo de la cancha luego de la tanda de penaltis.  La necesidad de ropa nueva y una intensa fisioterapia en un par de tobillos casi rotos en los asientos de madera de Wembley.
 2005 - Middlesbrough y el día que el penal de Robbie Fowler en tiempo de descuento para clasificar a Europa rodó hacia el olvido.
 Y luego el pequeño detalle de los Queens Park Rangers -- el día que pensamos que lo habíamos visto todo, el día que Agüero grabó su imagen de él, sin camiseta y girando el brazo, en nuestras cortezas cerebrales.
 Los fans del City estarían mintiendo si dijeran que todo esto ha sido una brisa.  Yo estaría mintiendo si dijera que cualquiera de los aficionados del City que se comieron las uñas esta semana desearía un drama similar el domingo.  El Manchester City, inmerso como está en un cuento inacabable de altos y bajos, podía tener otra cosa en mente.
results.title: Los Citizens son veteranos en alegría y desesperación del día final

results.body:
Si gana, sería el cuarto título de Liga del Manchester City y el segundo en tres años.  El Liverpool, que ha ganado 18, cerraría con el título la sequía más larga de su historia: 24 años sin una liga.  Todo está casi sellado en el descenso.  El Fulham londinense y el Cardiff City galés ya son equipos de Segunda División.
 Mientras eso sucede en Inglaterra, en Alemania 'Pep' Guardiola, DT del Bayern Munich, declaró estar preparado para el tradicional baño de cerveza que servirá para festejar el título nacional número 24 del club, tras la disputa del último partido del campeonato, hoy 10 de mayo, frente al Stuttgart.
 "Sé que es una tradición y me gustan las tradiciones.  Si los jugadores lo quieren, lo pueden hacer.  De todas formas, yo no tengo pelo", dijo el entrenador español, que espera con impaciencia la celebración de un título que el equipo bávaro consiguió el pasado 25 de marzo.
 Para el duelo ante los andaluces, el Atlético tiene la duda del hispano-brasileño Diego Costa, por una lesión muscular en el muslo derecho.  El club se ha limitado a señalar que el delantero está "pendiente de evolución".
results.title: Manuel Pellegrini, cerca de conseguir su primera liga europea
